146531900.review:
I played this version of ME1 in 2016, and it felt very clunky and dated then. After recently playing through ME1 again, but via the legendary edition version instead, I can't recommend playing through this version at all, even if you already have it sitting around in your library.

The story is still as good as it ever was, but the gameplay seriously does not hold up. 16 years have passed, and I think most people are going to seriously struggle to make it through the story without becoming frustrated by the gameplay. 

Luckily, there's a greatly-overhauled version included in Mass Effect Legendary Edition, and buying LE on sale is probably cheaper than buying ME1 ($16 CDN for LE right now, opposed to $40 for ME1 right now), let alone cheaper than picking up the whole trilogy piecemeal. There's a lot of changes to the game, with the most notable one being a serious graphical overhaul, but the most important change IMO is that [b]the Mako is no longer completely awful to use[/b]. 

The Mako is everyone's least favourite part of ME1: there's a reason there's no Mako in ME2/ME3. It wouldn't really be possible to remove it from the game without a serious overhaul, but they made it pack a serious punch in the LE remaster (the cannon will one-shot basic enemies even on insanity) and give full kill XP. 

It's not a bad game, but it's been made fully obsolete by the remaster.

142216581.review:
Illuminated by the eerie glow of my gaming rig, I sit down on a frozen evening, sequestered in my Arctic refuge, ready to embark on a nostalgic voyage through a galaxy far, far away. As Kiba Snowpaw, a lonely Ice Wolf hailing from an icy planet, who's spent over three and a half decades immersing in games, anime, and manga, my expectations are as high as the snow-capped peaks outside my window. The life of a solitary furry may be bracing, but the warmth of my passion for gaming, bolstered by the countless projects I've funded on Kickstarter and Patreon, sustains me. You see, my contribution has not only been monetary, but also emotional. This isn't just a hobby; it's a lifeline, a haven from the biting winds of my reality, a sanctuary for a troubled mind haunted by depression and the labor of caring for an ailing father.

So, let me dive headlong into the icy depths of the game that stands before me: Mass Effect (2007). 🚀

Remember, folks, I'm an old-school gamer, and I'll tell you this much: #OldIsGold. The graphics? Groundbreaking, especially for the time. The voice acting? Sublime. It's like slipping into a well-worn glove, the game inviting me into an expansive universe, every character meticulously crafted, and every dialogue perfectly scripted. The comparisons with Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic are inevitable, but this game delivers an experience far beyond the realm of simple space opera. This, my friends, is an epic!

The dilemma of choosing whether to embrace the light or to descend into the dark depths of malevolence, the tenuous balance between good and evil, is a delicate dance that Mass Effect choreographs masterfully.🪄 Add to this the robust lore and narrative, the immersive world-building, and the dynamic gameplay, and you're in for one heck of a gaming experience.

However, it's not all intergalactic roses. The black pixelated character bug at Peak 15? A disruption, a glitch in the matrix that fractures the otherwise seamless narrative. But hey, every gem has its flaws, and this one can be easily remedied. And let's not forget the dated combat mechanics and the monotonous exploration. The clunky Mako, with its infuriatingly frustrating controls, may drive you to distraction, but the storyline swiftly pulls you back in. The tedious elevators? Simply a necessary evil, I suppose. 😅

The expansive landscapes, though occasionally marred by repetitive designs, still manage to evoke awe and wonder. As for the squad-based combat, it leaves something to be desired, but as any seasoned gamer knows, the AI isn't always your best buddy on the battlefield.

Yet, amidst these flaws, there's a charm that keeps you coming back. This game isn't just about blasting aliens and saving the universe. No, it's about forging relationships, making choices that resonate throughout the trilogy, and experiencing a narrative that rivals the most acclaimed sci-fi sagas. It's about the thrill of the hunt, the heartbreak of loss, and the triumph of victory. The game makes you laugh, cry, rage, and rejoice, often all within the same mission.

So, despite the bumps and hiccups, I can safely say that Mass Effect (2007) is worth every penny of the asking price. Trust me, don't let the naysayers deter you from this incredible journey. And remember, #ItsNotAboutTheDestinationItsTheJourney. The game is more than the sum of its parts. It's an odyssey, an epic, a lifestyle.

So grab that controller, select your class, and jump aboard the Normandy. The galaxy is waiting. The choices are yours. The adventure is just beginning. 🌌

Final verdict: The game may have aged, but like a good wine, it's gotten better with time. A must-play for any RPG fan. Just remember: We are all Commander Shepard in this journey, and we all have our own stories to tell. 🎮

So, as I conclude, the lonely Arctic wind howls outside my window, mirroring the desolate landscapes I've traversed in-game. But within me, there's a fire. A passion kindled by Mass Effect. It's the same fire that's seen me through countless trials and tribulations, through toxic relationships and mind-numbing depression. It's the fire that fuels the life of Kiba Snowpaw. As I sit back in my chair, staring at the end credits, I know I'll be back. After all, the universe isn't going to save itself.

Now, time for some hot cocoa and a warm blanket. I think Garrus Vakarian would approve. 🐺❄️🕹️

141754553.review:
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

Platform: Steam

Mass Effect 2007 is a true masterpiece that defies the boundaries of gaming and storytelling. Developed by BioWare, this science fiction epic takes players on an unforgettable journey across the galaxy, where choices have consequences and the fate of civilizations rests in your hands. It's no wonder that Mass Effect became an instant classic upon its release and continues to captivate players to this day.

From the moment I stepped into the shoes of Commander Shepard, I was enthralled by the game's rich universe, engaging characters, and immersive gameplay. The level of depth and attention to detail is staggering, with each planet, species, and conversation meticulously crafted to create a living, breathing sci-fi world.

The storyline is nothing short of remarkable. As Shepard, players are tasked with saving the galaxy from an ancient alien threat known as the Reapers. The writing is top-notch, blending political intrigue, moral dilemmas, and personal relationships into a compelling narrative that keeps you hooked from start to finish. The choices you make throughout the game not only impact the immediate outcome but also carry over to future installments, ensuring a truly personalized experience.

The gameplay mechanics are equally outstanding. Mass Effect seamlessly combines third-person shooter action with RPG elements, offering a perfect balance between intense combat sequences and character development. The ability to customize Shepard's skills, appearance, and personality adds an extra layer of immersion, making you feel like a true space-faring hero.

One aspect that sets Mass Effect apart from other games is its memorable cast of characters. Each companion is brilliantly written, fleshed out with their own backstory, motivations, and unique personalities. Interacting with them not only deepens the story but also forges deep connections and friendships that resonate long after the game is over.

Visually, Mass Effect was ahead of its time. The art direction and graphical fidelity still hold up remarkably well, transporting players to stunning alien worlds and space stations that brim with life. Coupled with an atmospheric soundtrack that perfectly complements the on-screen action, the game creates an immersive audiovisual experience that is second to none.

Furthermore, the attention to detail in the game's world-building is unparalleled. The Codex provides a vast amount of lore and information about the universe, allowing players to delve deeper into the game's universe if they desire.

In conclusion, Mass Effect 2007 is a gaming masterpiece that deserves all the acclaim it has received over the years. Its compelling narrative, memorable characters, immersive gameplay, and stunning visuals combine to create an experience that transcends the medium. Whether you're a fan of science fiction, RPGs, or just exceptional storytelling, Mass Effect 2007 is a must-play that will leave you eagerly anticipating the sequels. Strap in, Commander, because the journey across the galaxy awaits!

141156070.review:
I can't believe I missed this incredible game when it came out. This is a top quality title with incredible art, writing, voice acting, controls, and animations. Few games of today can match the smoothness of this one. 

Likes:
1. The expansive universe and the ability to roam freely for most of the game.
2. Smoothness in transition between areas/maps.
3. Overall quality of the writing, story, and voice acting.
4. Combat dynamics and controls.
5. The addition of a usable vehicle to explore various planet surfaces. 
6. Character depth and different alien race backstories.
7. In-depth dialogues that added a lot of richness to the story, and the overall dialogue functions.
8. The overall universe that was created within the game that leaves room for much more story and exploration.

Dislikes:
1. There were two levels that, for some reason, never properly loaded the moving bit maps, so they showed up as black blobs. Probably had something to do with the age of the game and software incompatibilities with modern hardware/software.
2. The galaxy view map is a bit overwhelming. I wish it had some sort of tracking to let you know where you had already been and if there was anything left to survey or explore. I visited some planets multiple times by mistake not realizing I had already been there and done everything. Some systems were hidden to me until I realized I can "move around" the nebulae to find systems that were not visible from the default view.
3. Some key points on interest not showing up on the maps (intentionally). I understand the mineral points not showing up, but still is a strange story continuity issue... if you can "survey" a planet that you can't land on from orbit to find stuff like mineral deposits, why can't you do it for the planets where you can make a landing?
4. The game's money system. At first, everything is prohibitively expensive, then evens out, then everything seems super cheap towards the back 1/2 of the game. I ended the game maxed out at $9,999,999 credits and nothing to spend it on. It would have been nice to have more unique items in the various stores. 
5. No control over the ability points spent on your crew. I really wanted the decryption and electronics skills to advance on my team members before other skills, but I had no choice, so had to wait until I got to a certain level overall to be able to open the most hardened containers/computers. That made for a lot of disappointing backtracking near the end of the game. 
6. The all too predictable and poorly written love story addition to the plot line. Would have liked to see better writing around that topic, or just avoid it entirely.
7. Not a whole lot to entice playing through more than once. There are some decisions you could re-do and alternate story lines at key points, but not to the point where I feel it is worth replaying the entire game, but perhaps others do. 

Overall - If you really liked the original Deus Ex, then you will really enjoy this game. Very similar in overall concept (RPG+Shooter) and quality. This one had more features/finesse added on the top. Plus the ability to drive a vehicle with a functional tank-like cannon! Boom!! Totally awesome. If you catch this on sale, all the better, but still a good value even if it is not.

139198071.review:
I first played this in the mid-2010s, fairly deeply into the game and at the last of the explorable planets shown (Virmire).  Lost interest.  Tried again this year, and quit about the same point.  I now see why.

To put it shortly, the game is desperately overrated.  Once you get past the slick initial production values and any nerd-excitement over a game that tries to be a modern take on Star Trek/Star Wars/Babylon 5 -- once you are over the gleaming, well-made ad copy and cover -- what you are left with is a bland, uninspired, repetitive, janky kind-of-sort-of FPS adventure shooter made by a company whose forte is not FPSes, with many poor and frustrating design decisions.  And on top of all that, you start to notice the jank and lack of polish in actual gameplay more and more as you get further in.

To begin with, so much can be forgiven for a game with a great story.  I mean, I used to play Sierra point-and-click adventures, and where is the gameplay in them.  Unfortunately, that's likely the greatest failure of ME.  You can see the development team definitely put some effort into worldbuilding, trying to create a gritty game universe in the vein of the aforementioned movies/series.  But, like so much these days, the voice actors do what they can, but the writing is flat, the characters deep only in a ham-handed sense, and the story watery and paper-thin, but done in a sullen and emphatic way.  I mean, if you're going to be superficial and trite, at least say it like you mean it and add little twitches, right?

The dialogue honestly feels like an extended military recruitment ad for people of a more liberal mindset, ranging from bland cliche to outright implausible and unintentionally funny.  Or just cringy -- quite a bit to cringe at in there.

But the gameplay, right?  A BioWare adventure that's an FPS shooter, how fun!  It is, at first.  Then you see the battles (and their set locations) are repetitive, flat/boring, and often silly (did you know that you are the only person in the universe with a vehicle, and you can just mow down enemies galore while they stand relatively still like target practice, firing weapons that travel slow enough to be easily dodged, and when they do hit, they tick away your vehicle's shields/armor ever so gently, even at the highest difficulty levels?).  Once you've visited 10 planets/fighting locations, you have now seen all the set locations and maps that you are going to see, over and over again, for the rest of the game, with a few slight twists here and there.

It tries to come off as a tactical game -- you can give orders to your 2 companions and tell them to go here, take cover there, but you quickly realize that this is not only unnecessary, but poorly-implemented and they don't really listen to you very well anyway.  The enemy AI is dumb, and so is your companions' AI.  Tactics are silly here anyway, just shoot enemies like a 90s FPS and you'll do fine.

Loot is visually-undifferentiated versions of the same guns (okay, maybe slight color differences, but same model and only a few skins), listed textually.  At some point, you stop caring, and I was forced to deal with it when the game said I was approaching the limit of 250 items to process.  And once you've seen a few, you've seen them all.  And then you *do* have to *process* them.  It's tedious as hell and, well, dumb.  Streamlined ad absurdum.

Strangely, one of the design choices that aggravated me most was the slow movement.  You walk/jog along pretty slowly, but can sprint languidly for up to 5 seconds, after which you have to wait 20 seconds for stamina to recharge.  And there's a lot of empty walking and backtracking -- imagine any BioWare adventure where the characters all walk really slowly.

And then the vehicular planetary exploration seems fun -- I was excited when I first saw it, thinking, wow, like Starflight of old!  But, spoiler, it ends up being a slow, tedious slog to find locations on the planet, especially if you'd like to be completionist and find it all, with some of them behind very difficult-to-negotiate cliffs and mountain crags that will have you crawling out of your skin saying, okay, I'm done, let me just move past this stupid thing; why is there no flying vehicle anyway?  How does this heavy supertank, which must be super-valuable since it's the only wheeled combat vehicle in the universe, get back up in to the ship anyway?

And the sci-fi aspect -- I mean, a field of so much potential -- ends up being undermined by the fact that everywhere you go, every planet you find, every icon on the mini-map you explore, you find...  more stuff like a certain religious leader's writings, or an insignia from a colony.  It's narcissistic sci-fi where mankind looks out at the universe and sees only himself.  Like if I finally made it to Proxima Centauri, visited an exotic world, and found a Devo CD and a Bible.  Boring and uninspired.  Whip it good, though, I guess.

But, again, back to the fact that, in the end, this is a story game, first and foremost, and that's where it must be judged most strictly.  The story is in line with 2010s superhero movie stories.  Take an implausible comic-book-villain in a story written by people who don't understand human interactions and behavior very well, but make it gritty and have a mature intelligent *feel* to it (like ham-handed allusion to real-world social issues, but nothing you wouldn't get in a 90s cop movie).  Myself, I'd rather have a good story told simply than a bad story told with sophistication.  It's... honestly, comparing it to 2010s superhero movies is not fair to the superhero movies.

As I mentioned, both times I have tried to play this, I got to the Virmire planet and just lost interest.  This time, the cap of it all was the ham-handed, forced Wrex drama before the mission on Virmire starts, and the way the main character and Wrex randomly, in the middle of their conversation, just suddenly have guns pointed at each other without the dialogue justifying it.  Like, they wanted to create a tense moment, but couldn't come up with the dialog to justify it.

And that was the moment where I realized, I just can't.  THIS is what everyone rates so highly?  And this was, by the way, the updated Legendary Edition I was playing.  It is definitely one of those games where the design process and decisions were heavily dominated by corporate execs and market research, and the creatives were there just to implement the mess.

This game was way overrated when it came out, and it has aged very poorly.  Bleah, why did I try this twice.

138524260.review:
You're probably better off getting the Legendary Edition because it contains the entire trilogy and all of its DLC, but this version of Mass Effect is still in good shape to play if you don't want to commit to the entire trilogy. You don't need Origin to run this either, which you will need for the Legendary Edition even if you buy it through Steam. You can still get the DLC for Mass Effect 1, but it's... complicated. Bring Down The Sky is worth the trouble, but not the other one.

Mass Effect is a very unpolished and barely put together mess of a game, but you know what? I love it the most out of the trilogy. It has the best plot and pacing of any of the games, it's the only one with a well developed villain with a satisfying final boss battle, the only game that actually lets you land on open-world planets and explore them, and is the closest RPG/shooter hybrid compared to the sequels which lean far too much into just being a Gears of War clone mechanically. Was it perfect? Hell no. The non-human party members are woefully underdeveloped in this game, the non-story relevant planets you land on are haphazardly thrown together with an abusive reuse of assets, and the combat is in this weird middle ground of being mediocre at both a shooter and an action RPG; though I will say that if you play this more like an action RPG and use you and your squad's abilities over playing it like a cover shooter, it's a lot more fun. But I can forgive all of the fumbles because the ambition to make a fully realized world based around a single sci-fi concept is undeniably here despite the lack of polish. And there are so many great things that you can do in this game which don't make it into the sequels.

At certain points in the game, you can make decisions which will affect party members' moral compass. Each party member has a hidden paragon/renegade bias which will determine who is saying the paragon and renegade arguments for Shepard's choices, and this can be affected by who you're romancing or the outcome of personal side quests or dialogue options. You can make notorious space racist (she's not actually, but I'm not gonna get into that here) Ashley an advocate for aliens or turn boy scout Kaiden into a human supremacist if you play your cards right. Side quests are much more in depth and usually have a moral choice at the end of them, which were probably supposed to play bigger roles in ME2's side quests if those weren't so horribly mangled. And say what you will about the Mako, but at least we can actually [i] explore planets in the space game [/i] instead of getting smaller hub worlds or linear levels in ME2 and fuck all in 3. And for the levels that are actually designed around the Mako, it's not actually that bad.

What I don't like is the god awful menu system for managing equipment. Seriously, there is no excuse for it being as bad as it was here. I feel pretty confident that most people probably gave up and ignored equipment management in most playthroughs, and I don't blame them. The game also has this neo-conservative undertone in a lot of the galactic politics, being very pro-cop and pro-military, which has not aged well. Too often is the role of Spectres as unaccountable black ops agents who can do whatever they want with no consequences portrayed as necessary or even a good thing. It was probably more acceptable back in the mid 2000s, but it's not a good look now.

Despite its flaws and how the series ends, I still love Mass Effect and I would still recommend playing it. Pro tip: if you are going to continue on from this game and play the entire trilogy, get the Mass Effect 3 Happy Ending Mod (aka MEHEM) when you reach that game. I normally don't recommend modding games on a first playthrough, but the base game ending is [i] so unbelievably bad [/i] that it still leaves a sour taste in my mouth over a decade later and this mod actually turns it into something satisfying.

137755379.review:
[h1]Everyone hates the 'vators, but I just kill Ashley cuz she's racist[/h1]

Here is where the whole franchise began, with a grandiose space opera RPG letting you choose the fate of the galaxy!

New and improved legendary edition notwithstanding, this is still a great game to play. While I did have some minor trouble getting it working, it DOES work on latest Windows OS. I have mine modded with MEUITM, allowing ultra widescreen resolutions for some very nice screenshots, but I play (and record) on native 2560.

Did I use 'notwithstanding' right? I hope I did. It's a nice word and I don't get to use it very often.

So for those not familiar with the game, you can choose to be either man-Shepard or fem-Shep, and chase some alien Saren around the galaxy looking to stop him bringing about the End of All Life.

There is a lot to cover so I'll try to be brief.

Outdoors locations are spectacular. Visiting new worlds is a real treat, as each comes with its own skyline, planet surface, terrain, climate, and hazards (in the form of a short danger timer when you exit your rover). Sure, it isn't perfect - there are some things that need a bit of work, things like gravity and related physics, as not every planet is going to be earth-normal 0.97-1.1G (depending on where you are standing on the planet).

Indoor locations ... well, they can get repetitive fast. It's like every colony or ship comes off an assembly line, with no variation in structure, apart from some minor ones. The Citadel suffers from being too big with lots of running around as well. It could have benefited from an extra fast travel station at the Normandy docking station.

Gameplay involves over-the-shoulder 3rd-person combat, with a variation on classes breaking down to Soldier, Tech, or Biotic, or a dualclass of two of these in one. Each has their own strengths and weaknesses. Every time you go somewhere you have to choose 2 people to join you, so your current team will always be 3. You can let squadmates look after their own skills in combat, or you can choose to control when they use them directly - the latter is recommended for higher difficulties, when you want to burn down a Soldier's Immunity skill, for example.

Combat isn't too difficult. Even higher difficulties have their tricks. The Feros main mission, for example, has a section that has a huge pit in the middle of the area, allowing for easy kills via the use of the biotic Throw ability. One interesting tidbit is that experience earned is always more as a three-person team as opposed to rover kills.

My favourite class has to be biotic. I love the crowd control powers that come with it, and Throw is just amazing for insta-kills off edges. Lift works on the final boss, and Singularity is just great eye-candy, sending foes flying and spinning around the room... along with assorted tables, chairs and fruit bowls.

In addition, the game also makes use of a good vs evil mechanic, which is based off the decisions you make during dialogue. It requires investing skill points into to make good use of, but some points are also given for free when you reach certain paragon or renegade milestones throughout the story, meaning after 4-5 playthroughs with the same character you could potentially max these out without spending a single point. They often allow for better rewards and/or encounter outcomes.

Back to the combat again. For the most part, it works pretty well. Occasionally there will be instances of you getting hit even though you are behind cover, either being hit on the edge of your body sticking out, or as projectiles go through the cover as if it wasn't there. Cover does get destroyed if it takes too many hits, unless it's outdoors, like a rock or something. But cover can be glitchy too, as sometimes you'll want to get behind cover and you won't, other times you'll want to run past it but the game forces you into it. You'll know it's glitchy if you are on Insanity and you die in a hit even if you're behind cover. Well, now you know.

One of the things I love about the original Mass Effect is the number of skills there are. ME2 really destroyed this in my opinion. I love a huge choice of things to invest in, and so much of it is useful too. Another is the characters. There is a lot of funny stuff, some of it not immediately apparent after one playthrough. Leave Liara T'soni main mission till last, for example, and her dialogue leans towards the delusional side. Play the badass instead of the goody-goody and make Conrad run away crying, wishing he'd 'never met you.' Some admiral isn't happy? 'Sounds like a normal situation.' ;)

Notable voice actors include Ali Hillis, (who also voiced Lightning in the FFXIII trilogy), Seth Green (who's been in everything), Jennifer Hale (probably the most well-known female voice actor in the gaming world). These are just the ones that stand out the most for me, other actors like Keith David are also fantastic but I don't watch TV so they don't jump out at me as much.

So sure, you can buy yourself a Legendary Edition. But when the original works, is fun to play, and available, why buy it all over again?

Mass Effect? More like Mass Affectation! This game has got it all: aliens, spaceships, and a protagonist who just won't quit! I mean, seriously, how many times can Commander Shepard save the galaxy before they get tired of it?

135302696.review:
[h1]"We impose order on the chaos of organic evolution. You exist because we allow it. And you will end because we demand it."[/h1]
The term "must play" is overused - but describes Mass Effect perfectly. As one of Bioware's signature series, Mass Effect sees you playing the role of Commander Shepard in a space opera/science fiction setting, as you battle to save the galaxy from the extinction of intelligent life. While you only directly control a single character (this is an action RPG after all), you have six squad mates to choose from on any given assignment, and can mix and match as you see fit (indeed, you should mix and match, as each have their own strengths and weaknesses). As is traditional of Bioware, the story is incredibly well written, the characters very well acted (both in terms of actual characterisation as well as voice lines), the art direction largely incredible (the main menu, as well as the music, are iconic) and the game universe thoroughly fleshed out with details: there is plenty to see, read and do - just the codex by itself will likely prove to be too much reading for most.

While not an overly long game (one complete playthrough, i.e. all side quests etc. will probably take 35-40 hours), the replayability factor is very high - particularly due to the choices/avenues in the game as well as the "classes" present. The three major character options (Soldier, Adept and Engineer) play very differently and have different skills and abilities which affect the gameplay significantly. If you plan to use weapons mostly, Soldier might be your best bet. Biotics? You would probably want to go with Adept. You unlock further specialisations later on in the game which enhance this even further, and you can easily have three or four playthroughs with differing experiences, while not losing the entertainment factor.

Before beginning your journey into Bioware's universe, I suggest starting with the below (after installation of course; all credit to OP):
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=286766759[/url]
This covers generic improvements and tweaks which [b]should[/b] not be touched by the mods below.

Given how much time has passed since the original release, many mods have been created to enhance the game on today's systems. For these, you ideally want to use ME3Tweaks Mod Manager (https://me3tweaks.com/modmanager/) - it will make your life much easier. I used the below in my playthrough (many of which make a massive difference):
[list]
    [*]A Lot Of Textures (ALOT) 14.1 (vanilla-friendly, exhaustive and easy to install graphical overhaul mod; designed to work with MEUITM).
    [*]A Lot of Videos (ALOV) 3.0 (4K) (aims to upscale and remaster all prerendered cutscenes).
    [*]Faster Elevators 3.0 (doubles the speed of most elevators).
    [*]Mass Effect Mouse Fix (disables mouse acceleration).
    [*]Mass Effect Overwritten 0.4 (a collection of subtle textual modifications for a more consistent, immersive, Mass Effect experience).
    [*]Mass Effect Restored Light & Illumination Natively (MERLIN) (aims to restore dynamic lights and post processing to Xbox 360 levels. It also corrects other things broken in the PC port and some things broken in all releases of 	Mass Effect (bug fixes).
    [*]Mass Effect Updated/Improved Textures Mod (MEUITM) (Mass Effect HD texture overhaul).
    [*]ME1 Recalibrated 2.32 (this fixes a number of unresolved issues with Mass Effect).
    [*]Pinnacle Station Tweaks 0.6 (reduces difficulty of Pinnacle Station Hunt scenarios on Insanity to make it possible to win, known bug).
    [*]Saren Stages 1.0 (aims to both resolve and add to Saren's transformation throughout the game using hand created new meshes and HD textures)
[/list]
Most of these can be found either on Nexus Mods (https://www.nexusmods.com/masseffect) or through the PCGamingWiki page (https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Mass_Effect) along with many other suggestions and tweaks. With some of these, installation order is important - the texture mods need to go last and will not allow the game to be modified further after installation. The PCGamingWiki page has more information; installation can be quite complex, but is worth the effort.

While the two DLCs released for Mass Effect are not available on Steam, they can be added by following the below guide (all credit to OP):
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=519913125[/url]
Bring Down the Sky is pretty good; Pinnacle Station is just a distraction and does not add too much into the game, but is nice to have nonetheless.

Mass Effect is a truly meaningful/moving game in which you get deeply attached to your characters, and see the consequences of your choices as you play through the trilogy. Many games on Steam are tagged with "choices matter" - but in Mass Effect, choices really do matter. Actions can decide who lives or dies, who joins you on the final missions, who you alienate and turn from ally to enemy, or from enemy to ally. Not all consequences are immediately apparent, but choices are revealed and play out as the series progresses.

If you have not played Mass Effect before, you will probably be better served by purchasing the Legendary Edition and grabbing the whole trilogy. If this is not your first trip to the Citadel - it may not have aged quite as well as its successors, but is still an outstanding game worth another playthrough.

Played on Windows 11 Pro x64 with some issues and crashes - nothing game breaking, but annoying nonetheless. These could also have been a result of some of the mods, so your mileage may vary. It was also necessary to create an override for "Force randomization for images" (Mandatory ASLR) and set it to off (under Windows Security); without this, Mass Effect would not launch at all.

P.S. Mako driving is as painful as ever.

Now a classic. Requires extensive modding to be acceptable, as the port is sub-par and barely functional. There are plenty of visual glitches, blurry textures and whatnot, but once you polish them with some tweaks, you'll find there are, to this day, no other space operas quite like this out there. I was never into Star Wars: KotoR, Jade Empire, Dragon Age or any of the older BioWare classics (which I have beaten at least once), but this one (and by extent, the trilogy) towers over all of them. The combat is a little janky, true, but when did that serve to spoil the experience? If anything, it adds some flavor to the course. 

I never played the rehashed Legendary Edition, which seems to have split opinions into the usual camps: those who think the original is superior, and those who do not. The modding process is somewhat convoluted,  and the performance and visual glitches (like the infamous black blob glitch on AMD processors, which was fixed by modders eventually) might turn you off from this version, buyer's beware. Yet, if you are willing to put in the work, this could very well be the best version of Mass Effect.

131003529.review:
While exploring Mars in 2149 humanity discovers ancient ruins of a spacefaring civilization on Mars, leading to the discovery of faster-than-light travel through a phenomenon called Mass Effect. Within just 34 years humanity becomes a major player in galactic politics, human colonies are established on multiple planets, Humanities scientists contribute to groundbreaking discoveries across all aspects of galactic life. Whether you love them or hate them, humanity is here to stay and determined to make its mark in this vast and dynamic galaxy.

Enter Commander Shepard, the embodiment of humanity’s spirit and a highly decorated and dedicated soldier for the Systems Alliance. When humanity takes its next step forward on the galactic stage, Shepard is chosen as the first human Spectre, a special tactics force tasked with missions of paramount importance and given the authority to complete them by any means necessary.

Aboard the SSV Normandy, a cutting-edge starship equipped with an experimental stealth drive, Commander Shepard is presented with an opportunity to showcase their exceptional skills on a covert mission. The objective is to escort ancient technology recently discovered on the human colony of Eden Prime, which holds enormous scientific potential for the entire galaxy. The discovery of the ancient beacon was supposed to be kept secret, the situation quickly spirals out of control when the colony is ambushed by the Geth, a race of artificially intelligent machines, who until now have remained isolated in their own section of the galaxy and they seem intent on destroying the beacon. As Shepard rushes to save the colonists of Eden Prime and protect the ancient beacon, they become embroiled in a sinister plot that threatens to bring about the downfall of the entire galaxy.

I first played Mass Effect when the PC version was released. I was immediately enthralled, It felt like the game was made specifically for me tailored expertly to my interests. To begin I created my bald Commander Shepard and set out to explore the Milky Way with a spirit of discovery, a commitment to morality and justice armed with a keen sense of diplomacy. I loved the feeling that my choices mattered and I was having a significant impact on the galaxy.

The galaxy of Mass Effect is home to a vast array of fascinating alien species, each with its own rich history and culture. From the hulking Elcor to the pressure-suited Volus, each species is distinct and expertly crafted by BioWare, the game’s developer. I found myself spending as much time as possible learning all I could about these unique cultures. Despite their physically diminutive appearance, the Volus proved to be a force to be reckoned with in the galaxy, using their economic prowess to shape the standard galactic currency. Although the Volus are not prominently featured in the first Mass Effect game, their inclusion serves as a testament to the care and attention to detail that BioWare put into creating this rich and immersive universe.

The worlds that I explored on Shepard’s journey were visually stunning. I was particularly enamored with the secret research base operating outside the jurisdiction of the galactic government on the planet Noveria. The view of the raging snowstorm from the cozy corporate offices was particularly memorable, as I’ve always had a fondness for snow-covered environments in video games. Another standout location is Ilos, which is littered with ancient ruins and alien statues dedicated to long-deceased heroes.

The recently released Mass Effect Legendary Edition allows players to experience the entire Mass Effect trilogy. Although the mechanics of the first game, which is the focus of this review, may not have aged as well as other aspects of the series, it remains an essential component of the overall narrative. While some may appreciate the combat system, I found it to be clunky and unengaging. However, all other elements of the game are masterfully crafted and to fully appreciate the trilogy, it is worth playing through the first game despite its shortcomings in the combat department.

129623544.review:
Mass Effect is one of the games that have a definite spot in my mind for being a massive space opera game that I at the time never knew I wanted. Now with the highly flashy Remaster containing the whole trilogy on the store at a more or less constantly reduced price I found myself pondering between replaying the old game or taking a bite at the fully remastered edition.. I also realized I never got around to reviewing this legendary title back in the days so here goes nothing. 

In Mass Effect you take the role of Commander Shepard, malleable hero of humanity with a quite flexible past all for your roleplaying desires. Personally I choose to play femshep infiltrator in the first two runs since I assumed sneaky gameplay and planting headshots like a spaceborn Legolas was my forte. You have a character customization screen where you can choose between a few utterly horrid gnarly military style visages, it works but I can't say that it offers you a lot in the way of customization still A for effort. The rest of the game can be boiled down to a pretty great Star Trek: Next Generation season where you alternate between shipboard activities and sending your most valuable redshirts/crewmembers on away missions to complete objectives and find objects, mostly new guns, in an ever expanding universe of wonder. There is also  a RPG-ish talent tree that includes weapons, hacking, biotics, charm and much more but frankly this is a game where you can't bypass all the combat so some points in your main shooter are needed.

On your way through the galaxy you pick up a rag-tag gang of intriguing characters like an intergalactic nursing home. Every character is different and truly contributes to their own personality and quirks and as time goes by you end up choosing the same two most of the missions since they are “your” team. The standard gameplay is a generic cover based shooter that was a common sight in the elden time and it still works. Be aware that the difficulty does not amplify the AI’s tactical prowess but gives them layer upon layer of health that you have to snipe away with the many guns you find dropping out of everything and its mother. The constant dressup of the characters is frankly a chore so I would heartily recommend anyone giving this a go to crank down the difficulty and play it mainly for the story. Some of the missions let you pilot the worst interplanetary sandcrawler ever constructed and the random planetary treasure hunts that fill out the galaxy are quite dull. 

Now the meat of this game is the storytelling and it is grand! The game begins with a short side mission at a colony that's gone dark and in the end spans a galactic council, it's not so secret police, a horrible threat from beyond the stars, lost alien civilisations and much more. This is a game that you have to experience first hand and it is truly a momentous gaming experience even though the gunplay is pretty mediocre. There are few games I wish I could just wipe from my mind so I could experience them again and Mass Effect is for sure one of those games.

129605951.review:
A sci-fi classic for good reason and the pinnacle of the Mass Effect trilogy. It features incredible world-building and atmosphere, great companions and the best antagonist in the series, only lagging behind its two sequels in terms of interactions with the other characters (ME2 adds context and extra details to their stories and ME3 especially features lots of different optional conversations and interactions that flesh them out even more) and, this is the big one, in terms of combat. 

The combat system for ME1:LE was heavily reworked and with good reason. Between Shepard's inexcusably poor accuracy, shaky sniper aiming and the Mako's infamous controls, jank permeates this game's combat. Coming from three full playthroughs of ME:LE, I had a pretty good tolerance to and even enjoy ME1's jank but not everyone will.

Still, this is absolutely worth picking up if you've enjoyed LE and want to experience the OG titles, problems and all. Pro-tip: installers for this game's two DLCs are available for free on the following EA website (https://help.ea.com/en/help/faq/dlc-for-classic-games/).

The hype was worth it; Mass Effect is all that I expected it to be.

I had this game on my mind for a long time; my hesitation came from the fact that it was made by EA(!) and that it probably won't hold up to current standards. Then there was a major sale about 2 weeks ago, and I was torn between Jedi: Fallen Order and Mass Effect 1. I debated my options for a good 2-3 days. Finally decided that this classic is probably what I really need right now.

And I'm so glad I bought Mass Effect! While the gameplay, at least some parts of it, may not have aged all that well, I'm pleased to say that everything else is quite stellar. I'm not a fan of the shooter genre, but the gameplay was good enough to keep me engaged. The graphics look pretty amazing, and the game runs pretty well on Steam Deck, with some minor hiccups that are easily rectified.  The characters and the story is definitely the strongest feature here. I got really invested in knowing all about my crew and made it a habit of checking up on them after every mission. Everyone has a surprising depth to their characters that not caring about them is very difficult.

All in all, I'm very excited to see what more this world has to show and to return to my dear friends on board the Normandy.

128795045.review:
Warning: Slight spoilers and discontent ahead
 
Originally, I didnt want to write this review because it's mostly going to be negative and because everyone seems to love this series, so I thought it wouldn't help anyone.
However, now after several hours of unsuccesfully trying to first get my own and then someone else's ME1 savegames imported for ME2 (classic, not LE), the game wont help me either so screw that.

ME1 is a crappy game.

I know it's an old game and might not live up to modern players' expectations, but I grew up with old Bioware games and neither Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale, Jade Empire nor KOTOR were crappy games/game series, even if you dig them out today. Only recently I played KOTOR II with the Lost Content Mod and enjoyed it way more than ME1, although KOTOR2 is not nearly as good as the first one...

But let's get to ME1:

Pros:
+ a few interesting stories and decisions behind main quests
+ interesting world and lore
+ Wrex is a cool guy
+ the game has an end
+ the end is quite dramatic and I like the enemy they emancipate

Cons:
- boring planets and bases on planets that basically are all the same (remember the nicely designed surroundings in JE, remember the how amazing it was to enter Baldurs Gate for the first time?)
- catastrophic driving physique on planets (remember the fun races in KOTOR?)
- most side quests are super boring without a remembarable story and sometimes you don't even realize/are properly informed when you completed one (remember the murders you could solve in BG2? Man, I felt like freaking Sherlock himself!)
- most interaction with your party NPCs is not organically included in the regular game flow, but takes only place on your ship and feels more like an MMORPG fetch quest (remember the first time Aerie came to you before resting, Jaheira mourning Khalid or all of a sudden complaining that you're too nice to Viconia?)
- the most stupidly placed NPC ever in the tunnels of Feros -> a guy called Ian standing 5 meters away from enemies without being noticed or killed although being obviously crazy and screaming all the time
- fights arent tactic or exciting at all (remember preparing for a dragon fight and the glorious feeling of winning it in BG2?)
- as a result, leveling up does not feel exciting as well.. (remember saving every time you had a level up in BG to frantically max out your char?)
- all weapons are basically the same, some just do more damage, you don't even see how they look when you buy or loot them, so no motivation at all in the item system (remember the many unique, great looking weapons in BG1+2 with their own lore?)
- inventory management is horrible, if you have too many items you need to dismantle them item by item, click by click, and you will get spammed with items.. (remember the different bags and containers in BG2 that fulfill all your horder's dreams so that you never have to leave cool stuff behind? Or simply marking several items in a shop to sell them all at once O_O)
- besides Wrex and to some degree the Lady with the long name, I did not find my party that interesting.. (HK47, Bastilla, Minsk, Yoshimo, Wild Flower & Chai Ka... You know the drill ;( )
- It's just not fun and I only kept playing because of all the praise the series has received and my respect for old Bioware games..


And now I sit here, having put 30+ hours into this piece of whatever and cannot use my files for the second part (tbh I guess this is an Origin/EA topic cause I played it there and they switched systems when I was in the midst of playing it..).
The beginning of part 2 kinda depicts how I feel now.. and what's even worse, I have to stick with that racist Ashley, because somehow saving her (despite her asking to be sacrificed!) seems to be the standard choice instead of saving the way cooler (but still kinda lame) Kaidan...
 
On the upside the first gameplay of ME2 is already way better than ME1 so maybe, hopefully I will be redeemed for my suffering soon.

127299823.review:
[h1]A half-baked labour of love[/h1]

Mass Effect presents well initially. In the 24th century, humans are now interstellar travellers. We recently discovered the advanced technology of an extinct civilisation, known as the Protheans, on Mars. This technology is known as "mass effect" technology, capable of changing the mass properties of matter. With this technology, faster-than-light travel is possible, as well as a a whole host of technological advancements.

The whole galaxy is now within humanity's reach. That said, humans are not the first race to discover this Prothean technology. Many alien races have previously made this discovery. Before the humans arrived, the three most influential of which have previously formed a council to govern galactic affairs.

Humanity, of course, want more say in galactic politics, including (eventually) a seat at the council, but not everyone is impressed. Some humans fear that council membership will sacrifice autonomy, and some aliens are fearful or envious of humanity's grab for power.

This is what Mass Effect does best: Bioware's world-building is impressive, possibly the best I've seen in a game. Bioware pumps the game full of lore and history, as well as a multitude of alien species, each with their own history and culture. The races themselves are also richly drawn, with Bioware refusing to reduce any race into one single trait. Those curious about the world and its inhabitants will find enormous number codex entries, that flesh out the world beyond the surface interactions. Somebody obviously poured a lot of love into creating this world.

The storytelling and dialogue are also well-written. Characters are reasonably well-drawn, and mostly interesting.

So where does it go wrong? The further you stray from the writing, the more lackluster Mass Effect becomes. The whole game smacks of a labour of love, filled with worthy ideas, that was hamstrung by a miserly budget.

Someone clearly had good ideas about how to handle combat, including a squad system and neat tech/biotic powers, but they weren't implemented in a way that made the game any more fun to play. Constantly pausing to use powers or order team mates tended to kill the pace and tension of combat, so I tended not to use these features, and instead opted for the bland, vanilla gunplay.

Someone also had the idea of allowing the player to explore the galaxy as they chose. Visit any of the 20 or so star systems, and you'll find a bunch of orbiting planets. Usually, you can even land and explore one of these planets in a vehicle!

It sounds fantastic, but it really is not. What you get a small, bare, procedurally-generated landscape of peaks and troughs. Don't expect anything like plant life. Occasionally, there'll be one species of copy-paste fauna for you to drive over accidentally. Other than that, you'll get a few copy-paste buildings, containing copy-paste interiors and copy-paste enemies, to fulfil a copy-paste mission that you only get when you fly to the star system.

I cannot overstate how incredibly dull and not worth your time exploring these planets are. I would only recommend it to people who complain about Ubisoft's or Bethesda's open worlds being bland, just you can appreciate how much worse things could be!

The planets connected with the game's few main missions are usually better thought out and more interesting. If you are going to play this game, this would be my firm recommendation: as much as possible, don't stray from the main mission. You may need to do some side missions to grind your level up, if things are difficult, but DO NOT approach this game with a completionist mindset!

I often found, as well, that the game would resort to a tell-don't-show mindset all too often. I found, for example, an old Prothean site on one of the various bland planets you could explore. I hopped out, and interacted with it. I then got three text messages pop up on screen (each with a single dismiss button) that outlined, in brief, some visions that my character was having. In most AAA games, this would have been a breathtaking cinematic. In Mass Effect, it's a wall of text, laid over the sight of your character standing there, doing nothing. Again, with a better budget, this game could have been so much more.

Inventory management sucks as well. You get to carry 150 items, that's it. After that, new items are converted to a relatively useless substance called Omni-gel (useful for when you suck at hacking, or the rare occasion where your vehicle is damaged in the field). Selling items is possible, but a pain in the neck. You don't get to sort items into categories, and you only get to compare equipment you're selling with what your current squad has equipped. It makes it very difficult to see what you should or should not be selling. Getting the notification, in the middle of a mission, that you're running low on space (i.e. when your inventory is 90% full) is frustrating and a little demotivating.

I'm writing this after my second attempt to get through the game. I played it again, remembering how much I enjoyed the first part of the game, but not really remembering why I stopped playing. Once again, I find myself in a position where I just don't want to play any more. I don't think I'll ever finish this game. It's just not worth it.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

The world-building is amazing, the writing is good, the combat is OK (but bland), and the side-missions/exploration is just incredibly bad. If you must play, stick to the main quests.

124957538.review: It's well-known that the combat and other mechanics of the original Mass Effect haven't held up as well as the later games in the series, but that shouldn't deter anyone from giving it a try. The voice acting, world design and soundtrack are among the features that have aged exceptionally well, and the writing is BioWare at its best. My latest playthrough of Mass Effect was the first time I'd revisited the series in at least ten years, and my interest in returning to the later entries has only increased as a result.

122390218.review: I loved the story. The options of dialogue and the possible outcomes of certain quests. I only played this title once, because when I first bought it in 2014 or so, it would crash at the same point in the story repeatetly. Unfortunately for me, I didn't like all the quests with multiple endings, but most of them. There are some weird mechanics in the game, like it's implementation of money. This sounds odd, but there aren't really any useful items to buy in shops. Mainly, because there aren't many shops at all. Throughout the entire game, I stumbled upon 3 shops and bought 2 types of armor. That's it. The gameplay is fine, but you cannot switch to a controller. The skill system is also quite confusing. For some reason, you can be proficient with the shotgun, but you only unlock it, after putting a certain amount of points into pistols. Half-way through, I forgot, that there even are any skills, which might underline the role they play within the game. The game itsself is quite easy with some frustrating checkpoints, so you'll be needing to save now and then. There are also a lot of bugs, but the most notable and infuriating ones are; The camera jumps, whenever your character walks over a slab and the sound of a million footsteps, if you disable the framelock, and your character being incabable of stepping over slabs. The soundtrack is weirdly terrible. As are the soundeffects. The sidecharacters are great and consistent, but unfortunately you cannot romance all of them. All in all, I had a lot of fun, even with all the glitches and flaws and I'm excited for the next game! 8/10

121256935.review:
The main questline was very fun! I thoroughly enjoyed the story and interacting with my companions. However, while this must have been a revolutionary game for its time, it aged like milk. 
Wooden voice acting, grindy repetitive side quests with the same 3 interior map layouts recycled, infuriating vehicle combat and physics, clunky AI pathing making companions stuck behind doors and cover, extremely long unskippable cutscenes every time you used an elevator or switched planets, and a bunch of other stuff severely hurt my experience. 
That said, the knowledge that some of my choices will carry over into Mass Effect 2 made me think more about the decisions I made while playing, leaving me excited to try out the sequel. 
I would probably just recommend getting Legendary Edition though.
6/10

118985845.review: I had been hearing and seeing stuff about Mass Effect since before 2010, and most of it good. Even if it weren't, the bits I was picking up continued to encourage me to get this game. Simply watching it, or listening to it, wasn't enough. Fortunately, the copy I have I got on sale. At first, this game looked like a Halo rip-off. A diverse cast of characters in an action heavy sci-fi-space-opera in which the gamer gets to go around shooting stuff. What I was hearing about this game sounded much more intriguing. Mass Effect has been on the market long enough that finding lower priced copies is easier to come across. This game is just about worth any price point, at least any price point under $100. The concept is inventive without being oppressive or offensive. At least, the way I play. Customizable super powers in a space opera with plausible scientific concepts! That's fun stuff! It's made by the same people who made Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, and The Citadel in Mass Effect serves similar purpose as Planet Taris, but with more happening sooner. It's possible the ideas present in this game had been in the heads of the developers before they began work on KOTOR. Any RPG veteran will be accustomed to running into the non-playable characters that you begin to come across more often within half a day's play who ask you the gamer to start getting more active with going about doing random favors. Fortunately, at least, from what I see so far, all that extra stuff doesn't get in the way of experiencing the game's core premise. The more you do of the favors, the more stuff is available, the more interesting the game gets. There are those creative types out there who's experience is taking too long to decide how to customize their character, and find themselves putting the game down before they've actually played 40 minutes of gameplay. This game came out prior to 2010. Even by then, games had gotten sophisticated enough to allow people the option of customizing characters to seemingly no end before getting to so much as the first cutscene. The version I'm playing is not the remastered version that came out prior to 2022, but I don't feel i'm lacking anything. The game looks good and plays nice. The animations look more polished and believable. It's pacing is a little quicker than what we get in KOTOR, and that seems to be part of its strength, pun not quite intended. Your character comes with a brief backstory to help the gamer get into the game more quickly. Things don't really slow down after the first 15 minute threshold. If there are 2 things I would change about the PC version it's the option to use a controller, and a better musical score. Parts of the score are more memorable, but this game needed someone like the composer for the Zelda games, especially Wind Waker, or like Marty O'Donnell, or like Jeremy Soule. Characters are multi-layered. People can still play this game as though they're trying to get a less positive reaction out of other characters, and the main characters still exhibit a certain level of higher honor. I really appreciate how the developers and producers didn't skimp on the writing. If you want to be stylish in this game that is entirely possible, and characters still don't sound like idiots, or bratty. Be prepared for more adult content and adult language. Even if you play in such manner that doesn't always involve getting naked with aliens you're probably bound to come across some stuff that is better projected while there's someone in the room who's at least 17.

Still so god damn good after all these years 

Mass Effect 1 was the first game I can remember where I followed every single pre-release news/screenshots/trailers I could and I wasn't disappointed back in 2007 when it came out on 360.

The atmosphere in ME1 is top notch especially with some good texture mods to bring this more in line with a real remaster.

Don't buy the god awful "Legendary Edition" it ruins the lighting and aesthetics this game was striving for and makes some characters look completely different in a bad way.

If for whatever reason you haven't played this one pick it up and look into how to get some decent vanilla inspired texture mods running and you won't be disappointed, Just be aware that this game is an RPG first and a shooter second so don't expect to shoot every single gun out of the box on any class with pinpoint accuracy.

Easily in my top 20 pick this up if you haven't already

116447129.review:
Such a good series!!

I hated it at first because I didn't understand it. I bought it three times over 10 years on different consoles and really TRIED to like it...but I hated it.

What changed?

I realized it's not really an action game. It's a mixed action + interactive movie. For every 30-minutes you spend running and gunning, expect to spend 30-minutes walking and talking.  Once I adjusted my expectations and played it when I wanted a movie (instead of when I wanted action) I really, really, enjoyed it.

As an interactive movie series it's probably the best I've ever played.

It felt good representing humanity on a level never seen before and ushering in a new kind of justice that this fictitious alien society hadn't anticipated. The main focus puller is its compelling characters. The depths in which they went to flesh out the systems of other alien races, such as their religions, governments, military strategies, and more was superb. I got this game apprehensively after watching my streamer friend Berleezy play it. Thinking I'll just experience it vicariously through him, well that turned out unpreventable, as I got the game and didn't look back. As a new player in the series who completed every side mission except the collectible missions, it felt satisfying unlocking specific dialogue between characters and seeing how thought out the developers made them out to be. Overall a 9/10 game for me since its near-perfect score is hampered by the level design of the side missions. Not Bad design, but simple, and this simple way of clearing out a building time after time had me wanting more. 112340559.review:
Let's be honest: the game has a number of flaws. What makes it shine is the plot as well as its pacing and characters.

The game only allows playing on "veteran" difficulty for a start - 3rd out of 5 difficulties. Each playthrough on the highest possible difficulty allows going one up, plus an achievement. For an actual veteran RPG player that makes it relatively easy for a start, with a few fights making an exception. That's okay though: It's a good way to enjoy the story.

Now if You [i]do[/i] seek a challenge and are a good player You might find combat a little disappointing. Firefights can to be a bit slow unless You choose to storm right in, a cautious approach at times leads to boring 'exploits', the character build system is a bit shallow. You [i]have to[/i] bring two crew members and can't go solo. It's just not a good choice for challenge seeking, so do Yourself a favor and embrace casual play with a great story.

Loot is a bit weird - You'll get flooded with items, most of which are higher tiers of the same or even outright useless. That's okay, although reequipping the squad all the time do to the quickly progressing tiers of all the equipment remains somewhere between the joy of looting and busy work.

What's awesome here is that all the different aspects of the game are fun. A bit casual and flawed if looking deeper, but hey: It's not about that. Advancing is fun, even if the builds aren't super deep. Looting is fun, even if there's a lot of inventory clutter. Fights are fun, even if a powerful tactical approach may lead to the exposure of the somewhat silly foundations of the system. It's all fun and casual and that's why nothing distracts from plot events and characters - the true strength of the game. 

As always being the bad guy is a bit weird and only supported half-heartedly by the game, but then You are supposed to be the good guy anyway. Why not?

It might make sense to slightly modify the game through the config files for a few QoL issues, as well as activating the console. The latter allows to disable lighting, because sadly there is a part of the game that might have lighting bug out on modern machines (characters become black blobs). I found that easy and there's guides on how to do that.

You can import a character You play through with to Mass Effect 2 (and then ME3). Honestly though? Me2 tries to fix all the various issues I described and that does not go so well. A question of taste perhaps, but I for one did not like it and I find myself in good company there. Like XCOM tried to up the pace of slow crawl combat with turn timers (which many players hated) ME2 likewise tries to up the pace of combat in their own way as I read it, but for me it felt forced and kind of ruined the game. 
Enjoy this one and if You do: temper Your expectations, get ME2 on sale perhaps and go into it with an open mind. 
This game is too good for it to be easy to follow up on.

Overall I thoroughly enjoyed a casual playthrough, almost like a brilliant interactive novel. Can recommend!

111834697.review:
Review is purely based on running this version game on my pc. 5800x, 6700xt, 32gb of ram, Windows 10. 

There seems to be some sort of memory leak with this game. It will run for a max of 1 hour before crashing with a bizarre "ran out of virtual memory" error. Sections of the game with frequent loading screens and cutscenes will crash at a much faster rate. There is also a texture issue in a few areas that make all characters turn into pixelated black blobs, but this can be mitigated with a console command. 

The game was playable with these issues until I got close to the end. There are a number of cut scenes that don't give you a chance to save. This meant I couldn't even progress in the game due to the crashes. Fix attempts included re-installing the game multiple times, running steam as an admin, running the game as an admin, running the game in xp/vista/win 7 compatibility modes, disabling full screen optimizations,  downloading large address aware, changing every graphics setting, installing the 2 DLC packs form EA's website, downloading Physx, installing bug fix mods, console command to increase game speed, making edits to windows virtual memory settings, and setting FPS limits. Some of these seemed to prolong the time between the crashes or make the game feel a bit smoother without fully fixing the issue. I couldn't find a ton of help online, so perhaps the issues are mostly related to AMD CPUs. I even found people with pre-ryzen AMD CPUs who were having the same issues 10 years ago. 

In the end I installed the game on my old laptop with an Intel Ivy Bridge i5 and it allowed me to finish it. I think the remastered trilogy makes sense if you don't own any of them (I purchased this game before the remastered triology came out).

108271580.review:
Picked this game up a few years ago and played almost to the end of the first mission on Eden Prime, then neglected it until recently. My initial impression was "meh". Okay but nothing special.

So glad I gave it another try recently. I'm now well and truly in deep and absolutely loving it! Okay so its not the best looking game, but what do you expect for a game thats 14 years old? The release of the Legendary version should help address that.

But the absolute best thing about this game is the story and characters. It plays more like an interstellar detective story, as you embark on various missions, chasing leads, searching for artefacts and helping (or hunting) various people along the way.

For people that love shooters, the battle sequences can be a bit samey and there aren't many tactics, besides using your special abilities at the right times and taking cover whenever you can. Other than that its mostly mashing the fire button. While you can order your squad mates to move, you can't make any use of their abilities. Vehicles such as the Mako, for planetary exploration do add some variety.

Developing your character's abilities and those of your squad is quite satisfying, as is upgrading your loadouts, when you acquire new weapons, armour etc.

There is a LOT of talking to do to a wide range of NPCs that feature heavily throughout the game. Necessary both to obtain new missions and earn XP. Some may find this boring, but for me it provides a nice break from the shooting.

My main gripe about this game is the movement, which feels slow and laboured when you frequently have to travel long distances on foot. The Mako (an armed all-terrain vehicle) doesn't feel all that fast in the open terrain settings...although it sure beats walking.

If you can get past a few minor drawbacks, its a great, absorbing game that will eat up large chunks of your free time.

106454315.review:
Mass Effect 1 es un buen inicio.
Al juego es evidente que los años le pasaron por encima, no solo por graficos sino tambien por gameplay.
Mass Effect 1 es 50% gameplay shooter 50% Narrativa con decisiones y opciones, y lamentablemente la primera mitad es muy mala y la otra tiene defectos.
La jugabilidad es muy tosca, el feedback de los disparos es nulo, sentis que estas tirando rayitos rojos a esponjas de balas con skin diferentes, ninguno reacciona a los disparos o daño que haces, todos quedan de pie disparandote sin mas.
Los movimientos de camara fija cuando corres es horrible, era un horror poder cambiar armas, siempre que queria cambiar de arma tenia que hacerlo 2 veces por que nunca cambiaba el arma a la primera.
Los compañeros muchas veces hacian idioteces propias de una IA imbecil aunque les ordenara cosas totalmente diferentes.
Este apartado es posiblemente lo mas verga de este juego.

Por otro lado me gusto tanto la narrativa del juego, como algunos de sus personajes y lore.
Si, detesto demasiado el hecho de que sea un juego donde los comentarios que hagas y como las consecuencias de estos son MUY IMPORTANTES pero aun asi usen un sistema de rueda con "LIGERAS" interpretaciones de lo que podes llegar a decir, hasta casos donde la opcion elegida NO TIENE ABSOLUTAMENTE NADA QUE VER CON LO QUE MI PERSONAJE DECIA.

Fallout 3 hizo un mejor ejemplo de como poner opciones de dialogo, si, asi es, COMPLETA. QUIERO SABER QUE ES LO QUE VOY A DECIR EXACTAMENTE Y NO 2 FRASES QUE PUEDEN LLEGAR A TENER ALGO QUE VER CON LO QUE VA A DECIR MI PERSONAJE.
SI EL JUEGO SE ESMERA TANTO EN CREAR UNA INMERSION DONDE YO TENGO QUE TOMAR DECISIONES EN BASE A MIS OPINIONES MINIMAMENTE ME GUSTARIA SABER CON CLARIDAD QUE ES LO QUE PUEDO DECIR.
EL SISTEMA DE RUEDITA DE MASS EFFECT 1 ES UNA VERGA. PUNTO.

Omitiendo este problema el juego es disfrutable, tiene momentos muy buenos y epicos que seguramente perduraran en la saga.

Narrativamente el juego es por lo que brilla, no pude hacer el 100% de todo pero lo que vi me dejo gratamente sorprendido, hay muchisimas cosas por descubrir, personajes unicos con backgrounds interesantisimos y la historia que vivimos como protagonistas no queda atras.
Realmente la historia y personajes es lo mejor del juego sin lugar a dudas.

Disfrute un 200% mas este juego porque lo jugue con amigos que ya habian disfrutado de este juego y comentarios que hacian mas divertida la experiencia.

No recomiendo este juego en particular por todos sus defectos, creo que es mas inteligente ir y comprar la version Legendary Edition que viene con los 3 juegos remasterizados y jugarlo ahi.
Mass Effect 1 es un buen comienzo, pesimo shooter con buena historia.

105940558.review:
Mass Effect marked the dawn of a new era for Bioware, for better and for worse.  Riding high off of the success of Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, the developer eagerly created an original science fiction setting with aliens, characters, worlds and lore that are genuinely captivating. The world of Mass Effect, and the history of the alien races and the politics of their interactions really draw the player into the fabric of Mass Effect's story.

The fact of the matter is that the world building of Mass Effect does the heavy lifting, because post-KOTOR Bioware seemed to constantly struggle when it came to balanced gameplay. Combat in this game feels so shallow and the other party members seem so useless that I came to dread any enemy engagement that I approached. Dragon Age: Origins was worse, and the ME sequels did improve a smidge, but for all that the original Mass Effect has been celebrated for, especially in the realm of Western RPGs, its flaws are glaring and they will turn some people off for sure. I have not played the newer rerelease, but I am certain that Bioware relished the chance to go back and tweak things.

I said once in a gaming forum long ago that Bioware games weren't necessarily good storytelling, but they were great wish fulfillment. I concede that that's really a matter of personal taste. You can certainly enjoy Mass Effect for the story, bland as I personally think it is. You may even enjoy the story enough that the gameplay flaws don't matter to you. Nevertheless, get the newer Legendary Edition.

102143503.review:
My time spent on the SSV Normandy was immensely enjoyable. Flying through the Terminus Systems and bring the good fight to the Reapers and their Geth Minions gave me a new sense of purpose. Quitting C-Sec was the best decision I ever made.
The Commander, Sheppard, was a bit of a clot at first, he only took me on because he realized that I would be an asset to the Normandy and we could share resources in our hunt for Saren. We even managed to take down the Rogue Specter and defend the Citadel from a Reaper invasion. 
By the end, we grew to be fast friends, and I was really saddened to hear of his death while patrolling near Alchera. 
He will be remembered.

The armory was fairly sub standard and they kept overheating, so we needed to keep our heads down a lot. 
But here's the big question:
Can the weapons be calibrated?
Yes! After fiddling extensively with gun mods and augments I was able to modify my assault rifle to never ever overheat!

102108640.review:
This is one of the greatest games ever made. One of the most IMPORTANT for the many things it tried to do, and successfully accomplished.

The skill & tactical combat system is amazing. It's somewhat difficult to get a feel for at first, but you get the hang of it around 25%-50% of the way through the game (earlier if you're quicker on your feet than me). You can issue many orders instantly, as though you're merely thinking about them and able to execute them in an instant. This leads to many different tactical situations: you could quickly pull an endangered teammate out of harm's way to give them a chance to heal while you and your other squadmate cover them. You can use special abilities of yourself and your teammates against specific targets. Even the weapons and the mods you use are very important depending on the situation.

The subplot of political intrigue and shady business dealings...gives me an impression of a fully explored, immersive universe that has been extremely well thought-out. Dare I say, the level of a "fleshed out" feeling this game gives me about its own story, meta, lore, flavor, and otherwise tellings of its universe to me rivals even the likes of Star Wars and Star Trek. It's THAT good, THAT complex, and THAT compelling and complete that you're hard-pressed to find a comparable experience anywhere. The only other games that come to mind are any of the latter Elder Scrolls games (Morrowind to Skyrim); Morrowind and Oblivion were released before Mass Effect, but neither could match the complexity and scale of Mass Effect.

Even the dialogue system makes your interactions more complex: things you say and do on one planet will have wide and far-reaching repercussions everywhere. This is by far most apparent when you give a news interview to a reporter presenting the broadcast to trillions of people across the galaxy. There you are, controlling Shepard, making dialogue decisions that will have ramifications such that they touch the lives of people everywhere. Even THIS is something never before explored anywhere: the complexity involved in artfully negotiating a press conference to your own advantage. There just simply isn't any other game that offers a simulation of that specific experience, and that's only one of a thousand of different experience-simulations in this game.

I am really struggling to describe this game, the experience it gave me, and the impression it left with. I'll just conclude this review by saying this:

The is one of the most important games ever made. The 2007 edition will be eclipsed by later editions for graphics, DLC, and possibly some bug fixes, but you really need to at least play this edition of the game.

It's important for all of the reasons I described above, and more. It does a lot of things prior games tried, and did them better in addition to going its own way. You NEED to play this if you love games. You NEED to play this if you respect the history of gaming in general. You NEED to play this, as the air you breathe and the water you drink are vital to your body, so is this vital to your life's experience as a game.

I loved this game so much, I even went and bought the Legendary edition after I played it - which includes THIS game re-mastered, leaving me owning BOTH editions - and even bought Mass Effect 2 because my current computer can play that NOW while a future computer will be more capable of running the Remastered edition.

My score: 95 out of 100. There were a few minor bugs; one was Benezia constantly throwing me *through* walls and forcing me to re-load my game several times. The Mako's control system was a little wacky: not game-breakingly so, but it broke the immersion for me. Some of the ! flags for quests were not in the proper location, or didn't go away after I completed the quest. Also, most of the combat involving the Mako was easy. That's it. Aside from some minor complaints, and one bug with a workaround, my experience was as technically and artistically perfect as possible.

tl;dr

GO BUY THIS GAME. RIGHT NOW.
