99388343.review:
Mass Effect holds a special place in my heart. Played it multiple times through when it came out, was one of those comforting periods where you could just get absorbed into that world. Having a lot of elements from classic scifi-fantasy like Star Wars, Firefly, Halo, LOTR, Lovecraftian horror, even Star Trek with a picture of a future where species try to cooperate and can thrive as a result, having hope for progress. It's derivative sure, but inspired. And even if no single element is perfectly implemented, there's just so much working together to make the whole greater than the sum of its parts.

The ambitious creation of an elaborated space opera, filled with all the world building, story pacing, highs and lows of characters and events, twists and revelations, music elevating every scene, packed in a visually memorable and beautiful environment stealing all the best aspects from other scifi and fantasy that have remained timeless, without becoming too cluttered or clashing in competing styles. Not to mention the effort, resources gone to voice acting, making all the events and decisions feel important even if just a well crafted magic trick with little consequences, but knowing that an important part of making it all feel grand and significant is letting players get a sense of everything, placing everything there to entice a player to delve deeper, spend time learning about the world and its characters.
One thing I think is a perfect example of this was how even the main Codex entries had voiced narration, to lower the threshold for you to just sit back for a moment, let your eyes rest a bit, and still have an easier opportunity to experience and hear about the game when you need a small break. Reading on a screen in usually clunky UI is less appealing to read than just flipping a physical books pages that doesn't shine in your eyes, makes it always feel like a waste in other RPGs in even devoting resources to writing all that elaborate lore, something more developers should be mindful of, as it's not accidental how people tend to enjoy their books either physically or in audio book form these days over a PDF on a glowing screen.
The voice actors, music, design in art, use of Unreal Engine 3 coloured lighting and shading, all the locations, history, framing of conversations in that cinematic way, even the galaxy map and just going around systems checking on planets, investigating, small side stories to flesh out the world - Things that keep it together and make it one of those RPGs that create a sense of being in some vast world saving the galaxy one adventure after another.

There are many places that do show their age. 
The animations are a bit stiff, there's a limited amount of them, that does put a dent into conversations as all characters use the same pool of animations, removing a lot of individuality, they lack a lot of important facial expressions, the gestures get repetitive, and the sharp resets of animation cycles can look offputting these days. And the dialogue is serviceable, but not particularly excellently written or quotable. 
However like I said, I feel that almost paradoxically, the amount of resources and time spent on it, all the hours of dialogue, you being in those situations animated and filmed like you were in a big Star Wars-esque movie, that still manages to keep its aging parts sown together to make a good scene, being as corny and cheesy as those space operas can be, but with just so much more, bigger and grander, music elevating it as well, all of this in a way comes back around to make it stand above the issues present.
The combat is an acquired taste. It's a bit clunky, the cover system is... Interesting, the shooting is passable, inventory system is awkward and the loot blends together, the AI is meh. 
But still, having a pausing command hud that lets you think about your encounter, using party member abilities, your own, the overall look and feel of a combat encounter, often in big backdrops of significant events and large skirmishes going around you, and the weapon and ability effects are fun and the ragdolls hilarious. 
If you feel that the combat is still frustrating, then some simple config ini editing can make that easier.
The Galaxy map, exploration, could also use some QoL tweaks, one thing I didn't like was how if you went into a system, looked at a planet, but wanted to refresh your memory on a quests details, what it was about, exact location on cluster->system->planet, you had to zoom out of the planet, zoom out of the system, zoom out of the cluster, zoom out of the galaxy map, and then enter your journal to check up on your assignment entries.
The best fix for this currently is to just read your journal always first, and maybe just have the galaxy map tracker mod to bypass needs of spending time looking at all the systems while keeping in mind details of all three nested locations.
And the famous planet exploration with the Mako. To be fair, a part of me actually kind of likes it, some planets feel neat, the skyboxes with usually nice sunsets or orbiting moons, the way in the horizon it all hits you so vividly, some of the lazy landscape geometry comes together to create a pretty vista in the distance. But the geometry of the environment is lacklustre, and doesn't feel like it was properly tested to see if it actually feels any good with the Mako to drive in. There are parts where the physics of the mako and the environments do actually feel nice to traverse in, but those are rare, and mostly you're fighting against physics, game engine quirks and geometry. Coupled with how unnecessarily large the areas are, and how slowly compared to that your Mako moves, doesn't help.
Also a lot of recycled assets, indoor locations in these side areas for assignments.

But despite all of these, still, after all these years, I pushed through, because I enjoyed the world, the Galaxy, the game is not trying to make you miserable by design for who you are and what you can do as Shepard, it's the equivalent of a power fantasy for roleplaying, where you're not beaten down for being flawed no matter what choice you make, it's not a game limiting you to only one bad road after another and then scolding you for playing the game, you are a hero like in all those stories that people go back to time and time again because real life makes you feel powerless and shitty about your decisions enough already. Is it simple, corny? Sure, like power fantasies usually are. Yet, it's an evergreen classic journey we like to fantasize about.

Played on a 6+ years old potato laptop (i7-4710HQ, 840M, 12GB RAM), lots of ini editing to get the best out of visuals, but no HD mods, only MERLIN, game ran at a stable 60fps for like 95% of the game.
The PC port is its biggest weakness. Coming into this these days, it's better to prepare yourself to almost treat this as a Bethesda title.
Meaning you should first thing visit PCGamingWiki, Steam Guides, nexusmods, go through a very specific order of setting up your experience.
(Start game once, quit, follow guide for making sure CD keys work, then install DLC, then get ME3Tweaks Mod Manager, install through that ME1Recalibrated first, then some stuff to smooth out less ideal systems like charted worlds, I recommend, maybe Galaxy Map Tracker, HD textures and videos if you like, after that I suggest MERLIN: Mass Effect Restored Light & Illumination Natively Mod, and then maybe some config ini editing if you feel comfortable with that.)
Even then, you can expect some minor issues here and there.
(Had framedrops on Noveria, Ilos, and some planet surfaces, and black stretching lines on a few planet surface objects.)

Doubt I'll get the Legendary Edition despite my love for Mass Effect, not until they remove Origin DRM. This is still playable and enjoyable, as long as you feel that it's worth the effort to get an optimal experience. It could still run fine straight out of the box though.

98253338.review:
This is a story driven SF/RPG game. You are commander Shepard, and you lead a team of warriors on a quest to save the whole civilization. A bigger part of the game is fighting the enemy, and fighting is made very well, in real time, with pauses and issuing orders to your co-combatants. Taking covers, flanking enemies, using extra abilities and so on.

There is also a non fighting part of the game that includes story telling, quest solving, speaking to NPC's. Also there is a part of the game where you are onboard of your ship where you can interact with your team and find out more about them. They all have their own story, and their agenda that drives them forward. They make the game extra likable. You are more motivated to finish some quest when you know the background story. Also you can equip them in any way you like.

Except for the final fight that was a bit tough, I can not remember any part of the game that was extra hard even on hard setting. The whole game, and its concept is very enjoyable and I can recommend the whole series of this game to go on and play through.

97673788.review:
This is an old game. There.. that's that out of the way. Now you'll be aware that the graphics and controls are perhaps not as slick as something that came out this year.
Having said that, a lot of modern games could learn some lessons from the original Mass Effect in terms of story, dialogue, and inventory/modding.

A lot of people criticise Mass Effect for having a convoluted inventory and weapons modding system. Personally I liked it. I felt that it had depth, and offered specific tailoring for weapons and abilities, in a way that later versions did not. 
While a bit more button pressing and fiddling through menus was required than in M.E 2 or 3, I liked that my progression was so visually represented and that options allowed me to level up weapons and abilities in the way I wanted to.

Controls will take a while to adjust to after playing the far slicker 2 or 3, but once the old (newer) ways have been unlearnt, they're easy enough to manage. The Mako (space buggy) admittedly has some pretty awful controls, but again, it's just a matter of getting used to it (and knowing how much it's going to skid, as the handling is quite unresponsive).

Character models are pretty good for the time, as is character development. For me one of the biggest drawbacks was how samey a lot of the areas were in any of the incidental locations. (anywhere that wasn't written for with notable plot.. the variety is far superior in 2 and 3).  While it stands up the first time, it can become repetitive on a second playthrough.

Regular players of FPS are likely to find the combat underwhelming due to finding it over-simplified. But I think that more people will be playing this for the RPG aspects and story. And that is where this game excels. It is damn near impossible to not get involved in the story, and to not care about your team (well, most of them). 
While the shorter length means the game is not quite so fleshed out as 2 or 3, that doesn't mean that scenarios are less impactful. The game builds the whole way through and I found end game to be dramatic and rewarding. It's a perfect set up to the later games, and one that is definitely worth playing if you enjoyed the worlds that were built.

Downsides? ..Will raise questions about Mass Effect 2.

94050170.review:
Awful as a game, but incredible as a story, with spectacularly well-written, interesting world-building and an appropriately epic finale, which redeems this enough to make it something worth playing. It is a universe you can enjoyably get lost in, with an epic, surprising tale, tons of engaging sci-fi, warfare, & political drama, and a deeply, extensively well-realized sci-fi universe, where even the smallest historical & logistical nuances have been thoroughly considered & logged. There's complex science jargon abound, with nearly all of it properly rooted in realistic science or plausible science fiction. The game shines most with the many unique, gray moral dilemmas it presents you with, and the lasting, significant impact of many of your choices.

However, consequences of many decisions are badly communicated (even important ones), there are many instances of false agency where your decisions don't make any difference whatsoever (even in what the character ends up saying), the game is very buggy and unpolished, and there are lots of extremely flawed, weak, and ill-considered gameplay systems and mechanics implemented. The gameplay as a whole is a very weak mishmash of disparate ideas & genres, none well implemented or thought out. In particular, the Mako, combat gameplay, and gunplay are horrendously, laughably, frustratingly bad.

The game has one of the worst loot systems I've ever seen implemented (only behind Darksiders 2), and its loot management UX is just as bad and terribly structured, with no thought given to the actual use cases for the UIs. The overall UI is pretty awfully constructed too, including some absurd key bindings. Voice acting ranges from decent to abysmal, though it mostly resides under acceptable. The soundtrack is inconsistent but epic, unique, and overall enjoyable, and gets particularly great in the latter missions. The main story missions are serious, dark, and troubling, and result in many drastic, lasting consequences. 

Credits and shops are useless, since good loot comes from loot containers and it is nigh impossible to compare all your equipment to what is in the stores for purchase. More than that, it is badly balanced - I maxed out the in-game credits to 999999999 before even reaching the last planet, completely acquired naturally within the game's loot system, no hacks or mods. I couldn't put those credits towards anything useful either. Even the weapons are completely imbalanced, with half of them being stupidly unusable and inaccessible for play with any given class, and their effectiveness doesn't scale right. Halfway into the game, I ended up with absolutely OP shotgun & pistol builds that completely & immediately decimated every enemy that confronted me, and it stayed that way up into the endgame. Battle encounters lost all tension, enjoyment, balance, and danger at that point.

Despite all these flaws and so many other I didn't bother mentioning, it's still worth playing, because the world and story are so captivating, it is worth trudging through the terrible gameplay to experience them.

Must be played with mods to be passable by today's gaming standards, at the very least for the necessary graphics overhaul & optimizations.

93902303.review: I really, really wanted to like this game because of all the positive reviews, but I just don't get it. If you are used to other Bioware games that follow similar mechanics, then I'm sure you will love this game. My review is more for people new to this style of game or are on the fence about it. In the extreme, I often felt like this was a walking and talking simulator. There is very little action and the fire fights are short. If you were expecting non-stop action like Quake 4, forget it. Also, there was an inordinate amount of configuration into the characters skills, weapons, etc for a game that actually has very little combat. I suggest putting most of your skills into the talking stats. Yes, there are stats that affect your talking. This is what I'm trying to say, people! I hear that all the effort you put into talking with the NPCs yields some cool story twists, but honestly, I'm half asleep before those kick in. So in summary, if you're used to these types of games, go for it. I'm sure you'll like it. But if you're like me and don't really enjoy the constant dialog, then you have a choice: 1) power through it to get to the good parts or 2) just buy DOOM instead. Hope that helps!

[b][i]Mass Effect[/i][/b] is an action-RPG/cover-based third-person shooter. There are several classes, companions and weapon types. The game supports auto-/manual and quick saves. The character is customizable (class, equipment, appearance, background, first name). It runs on Windows 10. 2 DLC are available for free from the publisher's site*. The controls are rebindable, 4-button mice supported (the fifth button is not recognised).

Some in-game bonuses (i.e. +10% to shields or weapon proficiencies) are locked behind in-game achievements (not Steam achievements). The dialogue system is lacking - the answer shown can be very different from the spoken line; sometimes the player can choose only the tone, but not the meaning. The vehicle, the Mako, has very unusual physics and controls.

*https://help.ea.com/en-us/help/faq/dlc-for-classic-games/#masseffect

Too many bugs and literally unplayable.

I love ME as a whole, but this game has not aged well. On top of bad level design and combat that just isn't fun, this game has many technical issues that make it literally unplayable. I'm replaying this years later now that the remastered edition came out and it is awful.

Noveria, "Black silhouette" bug-
If you are an AMD user like myself, you will get to a point where on the snow planet your characters, for no real reason, turn into black boxes. The way you fix this is by either downloading a mod, or messing with the .ini files.

But where I gave up on this game was on Virmire (The planet where you chose either Kaiden or Ashley must die)
I get to the part where you encounter the indoctrinated salarians and the game crashes with the following message: "bad name index 1174405120/2723"
I googled this and found nothing helpful. This is where I gave up trying to live out my nostalgia and uninstalled this game.

I wont even mention things that have been said before like the uninspired Mako sections or the poor gunplay.

Mass Effect 2, my favorite in the series, is a damned MASTERPIECE in comparison to this hot mess.

I'm just going to say it, this game fucking sucks. It paved the way for a great series and has excellent lore and storytelling, but the gameplay and technical issues drag it down into the dust.
This game aged like milk. I hope they fixed this in the 2021 release.

I am downloading a save game and ME 2 as we speak. Don't bother with this garbage.
Maybe this doesn't happen on windows 10, but on 7 (even though this is the same system I played it on my first time) doesn't seem to work; especially if you are an AMD user.

91856475.review:
This is original that started it all, the greatest sci-fi trilogy of all time. Yes, it is that good. What makes this game so special is the quality of writing and world building that is second-to-none in the video game world. Forget today, this is vintage BioWare. The game starts slow, but builds momentum at a deliberate pace. Once you think you have the plot figured out, there is the iconic twist on that changes everything. The gameplay is a combination of action shooter, blended with classic RPG elements to make a wonderful blend of depth without complicating things.

While the Legendary Edition is the one to get (it supports 21:9, while this original does not), there is nothing wrong with experiencing the original and being able to play the Pinnacle Station DLC that did not make it into the remaster. All of the DLC, including Bring Down the Sky DLC, is not available on the Steam store page, but it is available for free on EA's website.

The Mass Effect Franchise is definitely worth playing if you're into Sci Fi and Shooters.
That being said and as much as I hate EA, save yourself the hassle later down the line and buy the whole Legendary Edition with all the DLC for $60, its cheaper than buying all three games seperately.

As for specific comments, the classes and skills differ in each of the games but in ME1 you basically choose do I want Heavy Armor, or the ability to cast tech / biotics. ME1 is more diverse with Renegade / Paragon paths than its predecessors, and as much as I hated driving the Mako over wacky terrain it makes ME1 feel much more open and nonlinear than 2 and 3 where you just get shuttled straight to the closed combat area. Plenty of quests, sidequests, exploration, locations, lore and aliens. Combat gets a little bit repeatative and you will not hit level cap on a single run of one character even if you do every single thing possible, which is annoying; don't try to be a completitionist the first time around because you'll have to do it all over again.

90871824.review:
Summary:

A bit shorter than I expected, but nevertheless a great game. Good story, interesting characters, fun side plots, and your choices actually matter. For me a 8/10. 

    
Full Review: 

    Overall Mass Effect is a pretty solid game. The main plot is not exactly the most original, but it still kept me into the story. Your choices do matter here, at many points in the game main plot or side plot related, you will have important decisions to make. And at least for me it was quite obvious when I was in a “important decision moment”. Like most RPG’s these decisions will ultimately impact how the galaxy sees you.
    The Game mechanics were kinda weird for me to get used to in the beginning, whenever I'm aiming with a pistol or an assault rifle the crosshair jumps around. But way more than it normally would. And ADS with a sniper is very annoying. The aim does not stay still it just moves on its own. Sprint is only available when there are enemies around, it gets old cuse I just want to run around and get to places faster, when I'm not in combat. I didn't use in game weapon mods, I didn't see the necessity. Oh and the MAKO is so stupid fun to drive lol.
    There are a few romance options, and if you are trying to avoid them you can but it's a little tricky. I wanted to romance the quarian Tali, but she's only available for romance in Mass Effect 2, so I didn't do any romance in this game. Fair warning the devs do try to throw a romance on you. 
    To wrap this up, there are some bugs in the game. You can install mods to fix it, but I was able to play through the whole game without needing mods. I do recommend this game especially if you want to port the save to the sequel. Solid 8/10.

[h1] A True Classic [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

It's a sci-fi RPG, which is so rare.  Even more so, it's a good RPG with great combat.  It's really a classic.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

Not much!

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

Already played it a ton elsewhere, so I didn't play it much on Steam.  Can't wait for the remastered version!

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

Always a fantastic game no matter how many times I replay it. It's great replaying it with a new computer so I can use the highest settings. The game controls on a PC is pretty odd and not that intuitive but workable and can be changed. Just a not to future users/buyers it doesn't technically support 1080p resolution but if you google it there are instructions on how to change one of the word files so it actually will play in 1080p. A VERY easy process.

Oh, almost forgot. On my new (2020) MSI gaming laptop Mass Effect didn't recognize my GPU so the CPU was running really hot with the fans on non-stop. That shouldn't be happening on a 14 year old game. I found online that with Nvidia you can change how all applications use the GPU. In the Nvidia Control Panel you can select Mass Effect and tell your computer to run using the GPU. Since then I haven't had the fans kick on once!

89924935.review: I might  be looking at this whole thing through rose coloured glasses, but I can happily say that this is my favourite mass effect game, for one very specific reason: While it might look a bit dated and while its gameplay might no nearly be as polished as me2s (I still find the weapon cooldown system more interesting tho), the game has the best story out of all 3 games, as it not only establishes a rich world the other two did not really expand upon, but also tells a really good self enclosed sci-fi story with a few minor annoyances. But the real reason that makes this game stand out is that it perfectly blends a hopeful, bright future setting in which humanity has overcome most of its problems with really scary horror elements like gross body horror zombies and people being mind controlled by a blob or AI that will just mercilessly massacre you. The contrast really makes it stick and makes you care for these characters. Me2 and 3 chose to go for a darker, more edgy and gritty setting in general which makes their scary concepts like people being turned into people juice not nearly as shocking. I think that your first mission on Eden Prime perfectly demonstrates this idea when young and hopeful Jenkins gets killed off and a nice and bright colony gets murdered by some deep space horror. Yeah Iam rambling a bit but I found this to be pretty unique for this type of setting.

89671527.review:
If you would like to get into Mass Effect, you need to play each of the games in order to get the most out of the story so I obviously recommend this just for that, but as a standalone game, I have a love-hate relationship with this game.
So firstly, what I like about this game is the story, out of all the games this game has the best writing and world building, that very much is true, even with some bits of awkward dialogue and deliveries. I love how every planet has something that is written about it, giving a much more lived in feel to the world of Mass Effect, I'd say that is what this game does best. Environments are varied and fun to explore, though quite linear, the story will take you to all sorts of locations that will each be interesting and offer different bits of lore in turn.
Now, that is all I have to say about what the game excells at, again, I have a love-hate relationship with this game, and the game continuously likes to make me hate it. Lets start from the top.
Gameplay for me is a bit wonky, it can be more fun to play specific classes in this game, more specifically the ones that use biotic abilities, but as for every other class, they can feel a bit lacking, and not only that the gunplay in this game is, to be frank, average. I don't know why they thought it was a good idea to make the weapons work in the way that they work in this game, somehow snipers are ironically the most inaccurate thing to shoot in the world, good luck hitting anything with it unless they are basically kissing you, shotguns are good if you can get close enough but in my experience, you never wanted to, and assault rifles were a bit weak, leaving pistols as really the only viable option, again, this is based on my experience.
Levelling can be quite rewarding, though most of the time a lot of the levelling is just buffing abilities and your character, same with squad mates, it never became a problem but I didn't really find it special, it worked well and I guess that's all that matters. 
Gameplay wise this game a lot of the times feels like your typical third-person shooter, though abilities are what make that system fun, experiment a lot with it I would say and you'd get the most out of it, I don't really have much to say about it, only that it really does feel like it needs some refining, the most I got to say are about the MAKO segments of this game, which let me just say...
I have never hated a vehicle so much in a video game in my entire life.
The MAKO is clunky, floaty, and way too bouncy. I found myself pulling hairs whenever I use the damn thing, aiming and shooting I found to be a chore, and movement in general felt like you were driving a bouncy ball, which leads me to the one thing I found to be the worst part of this game.
The Exploration Missions.
Before that, let me just explain about the linear missions, these all take place in the main story and aren't that bad, they have an actual structure, feel very different from each other, and just work, the MAKO isn't even that bad in these missions.
The Exploration Missions are the worst.
I will never understand why people praised this part of the game, the exploration mission are a bulk of the side quests in this game and they are mind numbingly boring and frustrating. If you ever wanted to play a game where every level is just the same randomly generated terrains with retextures then this game is for you. Every. Planet. Is. The. Same. I felt like I was going crazy by the end of it, if you are going to play this game, the do yourselves a favour and just do the recommended quests, these quests will have some sort of story significance or will make it so you meet characters in later games.
Graphically, the game has aged, a lot of the textures are blurry and muddy, do yourselves a favour and install a few mods to improve those textures.
Finally I will talk about the DLCs, Bring Down the Sky is a must for every player, it introduces a new species into the universe and has some significance to your character and their story. Gameplay wise, yeah, you remember what I said about those Exploration Missions? Yeah, it's those except longer and linear, with really the only interesting gameplay being the final fight. Pinnacle Station is the 2nd and last one for this game, it being a kind of arena based DLC, where you fight in a bunch of different arenas for challenges, this DLC brings great rewards but honestly, it's pretty damn tedious and dull, it's mostly the same gameplay loop.
Overall, if I were to give this game any type of rating, it would probably be a 6/10.

This game is the first in the series of Mass Effect trilogy. You play play a space Military Commander by the name of John/Jane Shepard. He takes charge of naval vessel with his crew on missions to Chase after a Antagonistic who want  the rule of Men and Aliens and destroy the Galaxy. The missions are in a third person recon style with a three man fire team. Here are some of my thoughts down below.


Pros:
The graphics are error free or low amounts of it Given consideration that it was made in 2007. having a game like this, was state of the art back then and they are are pretty good to look at. From the sexy Alien Asari to bury Krogen the graphics did a wonderful job in drawing a picture to  a world that is unusual.

The story with Dialog options: In this game Dialog options come in a variety of  limited choices. Tasteful and reasonable gives the game a comic book feel like the gamer is watching a cartoon with an fascinating story.

Great gaming physics: One of the amusing parts of the game is the land rover named MAKO. While on missions the MAKO is this Tanky buggy looking Vehicle that travels over any terrain. kind of fun to see it lunch off of a mountain.

Rich Story: The world is enveloped in politics, war and other aliens which gives the story more depth.

Cons:

The gaming A.I  is immature:  Part of the game play is to take two other companions on these mission that will assist the characters in battle. Some times the characters can not go around a wall and keep getting stuck there. Other time they will stand out in open and get shot and not take cover. In years development, this will improve in games.

No Controller option without Computer Science modifications. I am sure there is a way to code in the Xbox controller but for people who don't want to that it there is no option.

Replay ability:
There are two status that may change the story line one is the Paragon option and the other is the Renegade. depending on dialog and options the stories are different so playing it again a get a alternative experience. 

Overall Fun 9/10 and this is must play if your interested in the mass effect Trillogy

Mass Effect 2 will always be my favorite of the series, but this one is where it all started.

[h1] Don't judge a book by its cover [/h1]

 [b] So for me "Mass Effect" was like a discovery in a gaming world. I would recommend this game to literally anyone, even if you don't like everything that is related to the cosmic theme. 88027816.review:
I recommend this game ONLY if you intend to play through the trilogy.
The quintessential start to the Mass Effect trilogy, introducing you to the races, characters, crew, galaxy and everything in-between that makes it impressive. Unfortunately, the age of this game really shows, and the core gameplay is pretty poor. Combat is uninteresting and tedious, and a lot of the side content is repetitive and boring. 

Note: DLCs must be downloaded externally. Search "EA dlc for classic games" and you can find installers for them there. I recommend the complete package before beginning.

My recommendation is to play ME1 on a low difficulty to minimise the tedious combat, and focusing on main story content and crew missions and dialogue. I thoroughly enjoyed meeting characters in ME1 and meeting them again in the sequels.

On its own, this game is not something I recommend. The foundations of Mass Effect, and the story of Shepard and the only reasons I see you playing this game. Likewise, I would deeply regret playing the sequels, without having played this game. Trust me, it's worth it. 

Mods make a lot of improvements for this game, but their are guides online for those, so I will not discuss them here.

Pros:
Great writing.
Interesting characters.
Well designed universe of races, characters, planets and lore.
Curated missions are good.

Cons:
Poor combat and weapon balance
Class system is pretty strict, and allows for very limited character building.
Open world planets are bland and unimportant. 
Movement is dreadful. I immediately modded in a working sprint.

87645678.review:
Well after meaning to play this game for about a decade I can say with confidence that it does live up to the hype. However this doesn't surprise me one bit considering the experience that BioWare has crafting these kinds of experiences. 

KOTOR and Dragon Age Origins being some of my favorite games I've played in the last 5 or so years I was pleased to see again that this style of choice based storytelling with heavy companion integration is still a winner if not a bit underwhelming. I'd be lying if I said the jump to full protagonist voice over didn't slightly neuter the dialog choices. While excellent they are still not near the level of those presented in KOTOR, in which you will always know what your character is going to say, as apposed to a 3 word summary you get to chose. It's not a huge complaint but I feel it hurts the role play aspect and immersion.

Issues with the overall new-aged dialog interface aside the story is good. It was interesting to see a sci-fi universe that turns enough tropes on their heads to keep everything fresh and interesting. The illusion of choice is presented well and while a bit of a railroad track of an adventure it feels natural to play and experience. Add in a great cast of companions except for Kaid who I dislike because he is essentially just Carth from KOTOR and I didn't like his character there either.

Game-play is rough and the first hours as your just leveling up can be difficult but once you get rolling through the upgrade tree the difficulty nearly disappears as you ascend to near god hood. While not technically wowing it is fun to blast through later combat encounters. Side missions are a bit lacking and you'll grow tired of exploring the same 3 copy paste buildings and fighting the same enemies on planets with varying levels of mountains and differing colors but their are some that are pretty unique and good experiences.

While the planets you get to free explore may be overall lacking despite a few standouts with amazing sky boxes or interesting side missions there is one standout of exploration I must praise and that is the MAKO the way that vehicle controls and the absurdity of it climbing mountains like nothing as the physics freak out when it rolls make it one of my favorite vehicles in any game. Driving it is a joy, maybe not for developer intended reasons but fun is fun.

Overall this game is a surprisingly straightforward BioWare experience levels are never longer than necessary and the story is fresh and interesting. I'm excited to play ME2 and potentially be disappointed by ME3. Sheppard Out.

86797023.review:
I've only recently bought the trilogy on pc but I've played the whole thing a myriad of times, in short disregard my hours.

Even with my huge bias I can really only give this a "maybe" recommend, simply put it just really has not aged well. Combat is defintly at it's weakest here, you start off having a generally bad time trying to do anything ( imagine having to dump a punch of skill points to get rid of shepards sudden parkinson disease anytime you look in a sniper scope) to walking all over anything once you get your hand on some later gear/ having more perks (I'm talking any difficulty here, you start stomping over everything maybe a third of the way through). 
The exploration in this game is barebones, you drive over barren fields of nothing and do a pretty weak minigame or clear out the same building type here and there...really not all that.
Graphics...actually don't bother me/ holds up well given its age. of course if they do bother you there are mods out there to make them a bit better
Where this game still holds up tho is the story/world building department, I can still vividly recall the details of even the most minute side missions. They really do just stick with you like that (and virmire might still be one of my favorite missions of the whole series)

If you're new to mass effect as a whole I still recomend starting here but if you absolutly can't put up with the clunky combat you can get away with using the genisis comic of mass effect 2 to get the general overview/ make key choices. If you're a vet of the series and are just thinking about playing on pc I can't say this version has any benifits over the console, even worse if you planned on using controllers as thats not an option without a somewhat unstable mod

Excellent plot, world, and characters. Graphics and audio certainly show their age, but are pretty good for their time. Controls suck, especially with the Mako and with abilities. Lord knows how many times I've use a biotic ability only for Shepherd to target the wall. 

The truly major flaw, however, is the absolutely awful side-quests. There are a few good ones here and there, but the vast majority are:
1. Go to random planet
2, Go to building that is one of four or so models
3. Kill room full of enemies
4. Get item
5. Leave

Seriously, at about 15 hours in it physically hurt every time I got a new side-quest. At that point, I only did them because I was afraid of the consequences in the next game if I didn't.

Overall, I would say it's worth buying but I pray for anyone who embarks on 100%ing it.

85844470.review:
I don't understand the hype around this game, like this is an eternal masterpiece. It's just a mediocre ripoff of Babylon 5. IMHO this is the second most overhyped crap.

Most people point at Mass Effect 3 as the start of BioWare's downfall, but the first Mass Effect was already showing signs of it. The quality of the storytelling is way below their previous games. Just take a look at the first act: the game starts with a huge exposition dump, then the bad guy gets identified by an unreliable witness (who disappears), and a bad quality audio recording (which could be a forgery). This prompts the council to promote Shepard to a position of more power and less accountability than Judge Dredd, to conduct a galaxy-wide witchhunt. [spoiler]And after this the council never believes anything Shepard says.[/spoiler] This madness continues throughout the entire game, but let's stop here for the sake of brevity.

The plot is not just a mess, it's also highly predictable, because [i]everything[/i] is a foreshadowing, and it's as subtle as a wrecking ball. Still, I liked that on every major plot world Shepard can exterminate an entire alien race.

A lot of work went into the world building with all the alien races and galactic history, and the lore is indeed really good, consistent, and detailed. The problem is that most of that is discovered by reading the codex. You can't talk to navigator Pressly or Joker about space combat, you can't talk about alien physiology with doctor Chackwas, or talk about tech stuff with the engineering guy. The entire cast is underutilized. The companions each have one short mission, and they can only talk about one boring subject. The love interests have a bit more dialog, but Kaidan only talks about how bad the boarding school was, and Ashley only talks about how the aliens are untrustworthy. No wonder all players romance the blue alien girl instead of these two goons.

The thing that really grinds my gears is how the guest star, Lance Henriksen, is utilized. He voices admiral Hackett, who gives most of the exploration side-quests, but he's just a disembodied voice. He only appears on-screen in a ME2 DLC. Whyyy??

For a high sci-fi setting the part of the world you get to explore is surprisingly dull. When on foot you mostly go through huge empty areas with featureless bare concrete walls. When landing on a planet with the rover, it's almost always barren and empty and dull. On every planet the outpost is the exact same prefab building, even the crates are in the same place. The collectible trinkets are unrewarding. The side quests are disappointing and unrewarding. The loot is 99% garbage, and you have to spend a lot of time organizing that garbage, because the inventory capacity is limited.

The talent system is overcomplicated and underdeveloped. Can anyone tell the difference among the 4 biotic talents without checking the wiki? How about the 4 engineering talents? Can you tell me which talent allows hacking doors and containers? Hint: it's not Hacking. Weapon talents are kinda important, because this game tries to be a cover-shooter, but it's unbalanced, because almost all classes are restricted to 1-2 weapon types. Yet, everybody carries one of each weapon type, even the ones they can't use.

The game has little replay value, but it wants you to replay it multiple times to unlock class skills and companion bonuses. No thanks.

The morality system is also a disaster. You need Paragon/Renegade points to upgrade the Charm/Intimidate talents and unlock the respective dialog options. Then you need to use those dialog options to gain Paragon/Renegade points. This vicious circle turns role-playing into XP-farming, because you'll need high talent levels and/or Paragon/Renegade points to convince key characters. You can totally miss this this whole system in the early game, because you don't even see the charm/intimidate dialog options until you put points into those talents, which the automatic level-up doesn't do. [spoiler]Fortunately, there is an infinite Paragon/Renegade exploit on Noveria.[/spoiler] How could the creators of several legendary RPG titles screw this up so badly?

What is this morality scale supposed to be anyway? Good and evil? Lawful and chaotic? Pacifist and bloodthirsty? Idealistic and pragmatic? Dumb and dumber?

The biggest fail of of the morality system is at the ending. If you have high points, you can convince the boss to abandon his plans, but this only skips the first phase of the fight, and you still have to endure the fkin annoying second phase, so the morality farming was useless. Also, why does killing the bad guy cause his spaceship to explode as well? And why is saving the council so important? The aliens could easily delegate new members (especially the Salarians), and if they were so irreplaceable then why were they allowed to board the same ship? Ehh, I don't want to argue anymore.

Did I sink more than 60 hours into this? Yes. Was it worth it? No.

85103481.review:
It shows its age now in places but it holds up surprisingly well! I originally had this on my old 360, and when I saw it was on sale on Steam, I just had to get it. One of the best purchases I have made on here, its such a brilliant game, one of my favourites ever, and probably my favourite in the trilogy. 

The universe is so huge, detailed and beautiful. Honestly, this is probably one the best original universes in fiction, not just gaming. It really feels alive and that you are part of it, shaping it. The writing and pacing of the story is done so well that you naturally understand more of the galaxy as you progress. The music is also amazing, one of the best in gaming history, and it drips with atmosphere ('Vigil' is an absolute classic tune, and probably the best piece in the Mass Effect series soundtrack). The cinematic cutscenes are also surprisingly polished for how old the game is. Overall, the presentation, story and universe makes this an absolute classic and must-play.

Sure, the combat and the AI are very clunky and admittedly very dated, and the morality system is a bit questionable in places, but the story and universe does more than make Mass Effect a worthwhile play, they make it a fantastic one. This is also the game with the best RPG elements in the series, featuring a really in-depth powers system based on your class, and you get the most freedom to make Shepard who you want them to be out of all the games. The amount of powers your squad gets is also a huge bonus, making it an essential tactic to command them wisely on higher difficulties, and really be wise with their upgrades when you level up. I still love Mass Effect 2 and 3, but I do still wish they kept these elements in the later games.

Overall, an absolute classic and still well worth it despite its age. Let's hope the remaster doesn't get ballsed up :))

85049799.review:
Highlights: Internally consistent sci-fi world, excellent story, great performances, choices that feel like they matter.
Flaws: Clunky gameplay systems, dated graphics.

Admittedly, the story starts out pretty slow since it has a lot of exposition to get through, but paying attention to the lore details really pays off by the third act. I also really felt that my choices mattered, and while the binary Paragon/Renegade (good/evil) skill system is a little limited, it still works better than most choice-based RPG's I've played. I also love that the world is really internally consistent, with everything about its technology and politics making sense with each other.

The graphics and game mechanics may have been impressive for 2007, but playing it now they are pretty painfully clunky. While there are quite a lot of combat playstyles (guns/tech/biotic), the gameplay never really felt that fun. Still, it's definitely worth it to get through it and experience the excellent story.

Overall, this was a great game made me feel confident in my decisions - my story path and my Shepard are "canon" to me now. Unlike other games where I tend to want to explore every possible branch and outcome, here I'd rather miss out on some content and keep my "illusion of choice", so to speak. While I may eventually come back for another playthrough, I'm definitely going to play through the rest of the series first.

84780279.review:
Mass Effect is a TPS-RPG game, where you act as a soldier on Space Ship Normandy, and you get the oppurtunity to become the galaxy's one of the most elite agents for the Council from the Citadel, who decide every galactical cases in every system, however the mission where you will be review took a wrong turn and got an enemy, who have lot of power and connections and his goals are unknown for now, but all you know, he is against hummanity and his plan is evil.

One of the best thing this game has, is the story. What you need to know, this game is not linear. You got choices to do and you got other stories to explore. It's well written in my opinion, however there are few low points or unexplained actions, which not really makes sense for me. In general, the conversations also well written, however you can get some lines here or there. I won't explain the story, but you can get lot of details, which is why this game is so awesome. Well made, really!

If the story is epic, then what can I tell about the music? Makes it better. All of the music is really fit, what you see. Either if it's a dramatic moment or you are trying to survive, the game always give you the proper track. Top notch job!

Time to mention the gameplay. So, this is a Third Person Shooter with some tactical elements, not even mentioning the RPG elements. There is 2 part of the game. 1 part when you explore places, talking characters and doing your business, even traveling in space. You can talk most of the characters, and at big portion of them you do different path of conversations, which is awesome. Exploring places and doing your business is not really interesting for some, but the game is well detailed even here too. Sometimes, you need to perform choices, and those have some effect too, even if it's instant, but sometimes it will happen later, even if in later games. For example, one time I gave some information to a report, and when I was in an elevator, a news broadcast said, the report has succesfully used this information and caught a criminal syndicate. I mention traveling in space, which is came later in the game. You can choose in which system you want to go and what universe. If you there, you can find planets which you can check some info of them, some of them are able to survey, which searching it through and you can find collectibles, which give you money or even land on them. Long story short, this portion of the game is big, can be boring, but has lot of story in it in general and makes the game interesting to play with, and not just fighting all the time.

The second part of the gameplay, is the fighting. So in fights, you will can use 4 weapons, which are pistols, assault rifles, shotguns and sniper rifle. However what I didn't mention, depending what character you have, you are perform these weapons differently. At the beginning of the game you can create your character background, which gives you lot of status points on different things. This can change the gameplay well, also you can customize your character too. Going back to the fight element, you can use skill too, which can came from implants, or your omni tool, but even soldier powers. Every kind of skills as advantages, and you can also level it up on is status page, if you get enough XP. Need to mention the crew mates too, because you won't be alone most of the times. You can give order to your crew mates, and in figths, you usually have 2 next to you. They are also different characters, with different powers and and loadout, which you can manage too. Not even mentioning, your own loadout. Usually in fights, you need to control your teammates and use their skill if they are not using it, meanwhile you also trying to move cover-to-cover and do your part. These one can be exciting to play, however I wouldn't say it's hard. I played the game on Veteran combat difficutly, and it didn't had to much action... except two missions. The combat can feel weird, and has some issues, one of the is the strict controls and sometimes not activable skills, which annoeyed me the most. These parts are all right by the way, not even mentioning the different enemies and behaviours too. Need to mention the Mako, which is a vehicle you can use to explore planets. The Mako can fly a little, shoot with machine gun or burst fire with it. It's a cool vehicle and fightining with it is also good, however the controls is something you need to get use to. Long story short, the gameplay is varied and interesting, you need tactics if the situation is bad, but you can win with brute force too sometimes. You get lot of options to deal with the enemies, and also the Mako is an all right vehicle, but the controls in both parts can be troublesome for others.

One more thing I need to mention at the gameplay, and those are the side missions. Sadly, this is where the game is weak at, because even though there are some interesting side missions with okay story, there are lot of copy paste one. What I mean, for example your objective is to destory a group of pirates, and you get a planet with a pirate complex on it. You go inside the building, do your fight and take another. Destroy generators in a complex. If you go into the building, you might get the same layout building like last time, which is break the illusion. Okay, the room looks different, because stuff inside is different, but this can be noticable really fast. I notice 4 different building layout and I did like around 20 missions. It's kinda annoying to see this, comapring to the wide story elements. And also, there are 2 DLCs for the game, but actually only the meteorite one worth the time. It starts like a normal side mission, but atleast it has some depth and you can get really good items from it. So sadly this is not that good part.

Last part is the graphics. Made in 2008, and time wasn't that nice to it. I won't say it looks bad, because it's not the case, however there are textures, which looks pixelated. Not even mentioning, sometimes the light effects are too much. There is one big problem with the game, which happens on AMD processors. Some processor can cause the game at two planets to make every character a black pixelated box. This still not fixed by BioWare, but thankfully there is better version. If you experience these, turn on the console for the game, which you can do in the game's Steam folder -> BioGame -> Config -> DefaultInput.ini . If you there, find a line which is [Engine.Console] . Under it, there are two more lines. Under them, write the following: ConsoleKey=p . With this, you will be able to bring up the console with 'P'. In game if you see the problem, you press 'P' and write: viewmode unlit . With this, the lighthing will be weird, but the characters will look normally. If you want to change it back, write lit instead of unlit in the previous line or restart the game. So, the graphics are not bad for now, but back in the days, it was amazing!

For me, the first Mass Effect is a really good game and start of a amazing series. I really do like almost every aspect of this game and the details too. However, it's not completly perfect, but if you get use to the controls and you can get yourself through the graphics, it will be a really fun game. I can definetly recommend you to try out this game. For 20€, this can be a little bit lot in my opinion, but I would get it for 13€ for no problem.

I love the planetary exploration aspect of this game as well, the cheap vibe of the side quests has a unique charm to it akin to games like The Witcher 1 as well as honestly fitting it more with a modern take on classic Star Trek. Combat is pretty wonky yes but as long as you're not trying the Pinnacle Station DLC (which I would honestly never recommend to anyone) it's fine and pretty easy. Inventory management is a big pain but that's true in many other RPGs as well so it's not a huge drawback imo. Overall I cannot recommend this game highly enough and even though I JUST finished a playthrough of the entire series again, just thinking about this first game already has me salivating for one more.

This is not a new game, and by today's standards, looks like an average sci-fi shooter game but a great story never gets tired.  Mass Effect 1 is the start of a truly epic hero story through the amazing main character, Commander Shepard.   There is also an oddly endearing cast of alien characters surrounding the main character.  One of the best stories I have ever experienced in a game and one of the most heroic characters I have had the chance to play.  

This is the first in a trilogy series.  Highly recommend not playing backwards as going from Mass Effect 2 to 1 will feel very awkward.  If you do get into the story and character and, like me, HAVE to see how the story ends, get ready for a lot of work. It's quite a long series and I think you would have to be quite determined to navigate that MAKO vehicle as many times as this game required, to get to the end of it.  Of the three, though, Mass Effect 2, is my favourite -- and the Salarian doctor. : )  

I've seen that some kind of LEGENDARY edition is coming out.  Hope it's not just an opportunity to grab more money from fans of the series.

84490734.review:
Hace más de dos años jugué la secuela de este título, sin haber antes pasado por el original (sí, así fue, no preguntes por qué). Ese no fue impedimento para que se convierta una uno de los mejores videojuegos que haya probado jamás. Realmente me dejo con muchas ganas de jugar las otras entregas, y al fin lo he hecho con la primera.

Pero veamos de que va el juego (si es que por alguna razón no lo sabes ya). En Mass Effect nos ponemos en la piel del Comandante Shepard (aclarar que podemos cambiar el genero de nuestro protagonista, además de otras cosas), un soldado elite de la Alianza de Sistemas (representación humana frente a otras especies) que se verá envuelto en un problema mucho más grande que él. A lo largo de las horas iremos descubriendo la épica trama de este título, en donde como es de esperar, deberemos de salvar a toda la galaxia de una feroz amenaza milenaria. El juego cuenta con uno de los mejores universos ficticios que he visto. Especies alienígenas, planetas, historias de trasfondo, personajes memorables, eventos, etc., un contexto y trasfondo muy bien cuidados. Realmente te hace querer saber cada vez más y más, adentrarte en este fantástico mundo para poder así disfrutar de la trama de la mejor manera posible.

Como era de esperar viniendo de BioWare, en este título tenemos ciertas libertades a la hora de tomar decisiones, libertades que afectaran el desarrollo de la historia con diversas consecuencias, menores o mayores. Además, podremos interactuar y desarrollar distintas relaciones con cada uno de los miembros de nuestra tripulación, cada uno de ellos con una historia propia muy interesante. A través de nuestro actuar modificaremos el como nos perciben los demás, siendo de esta forma un héroe totalmente correcto, o algo más rebelde. Y debo aclarar que como todo juego de rol, aquí también tendremos un árbol de habilidades que podremos mejorar mediante puntos de experiencia.

Tenía algo de temor con este título, Yo, como mencioné antes, he jugado Mass Effect 2 previo a este, y siendo ese un título que me ha encantado, pero en el cual se notaba mucho el pasar de los años, temía encontrarme acá con algo peor que arruinara mucho mi experiencia de juego. Por suerte no ha sido así, al menos no mucho. Evidentemente se nota el pasar del tiempo, aunque llega un punto en donde la inmersión es tal que no te das cuenta de ello. Cosas como el no contar con resolución 1080p, las toscas mecánicas de combate, las anticuadas físicas de movimiento, las limitaciones técnicas de la época, todas ellas son cosas que afectan el gameplay, y se nota. Por otro lado, por momentos el juego se vuelve repetitivo, especialmente en las misiones secundarias (con las principales no sucede esto). Literalmente nos encontraremos con niveles iguales a otros anteriores, entornos copiados y reutilizados, enemigos esparcidos de la misma forma, y demás cosas por el estilo. Esto es entendible cuando tenemos en consideración que ya han pasado 13 años desde la salida del título. Puede ser algo tedioso y un punto a criticar, pero las ganas de descubrir pueden más.

La sensación que tenía cada vez que vagaba por los distintos planetas de la Vía Láctea, dialogando con los NPC de turno, descubriendo nuevas historias y demás, es fantástica, verdaderamente está muy bien lograda. La música del título así como las voces y las cinemáticas son estupendas, realmente se nota que quisieron hacer de Mass Effect algo muy bueno, que marcara un antes y un después. Los gráficos del título, si bien anticuados, no dejan de ser bellos, especialmente en las mencionadas cinemáticas o cuando nos encontramos en planetas con paisajes muy hermosos. El desarrollo de la trama y su épica conclusión son sin duda lo mejor del título. Como digo, el universo de este título es algo fantástico, digno de admirar.

Mass Effect es una de las mejores sagas que conozco, no solo dentro del mundo de los videojuegos sino más allá también. Si no les has dado aún una oportunidad, desde aquí te animo a hacerlo, no te vas a arrepentir. De hecho estás de suerte, dentro de poco se lanzará la trilogía remasterizada y puede que sea la mejor oportunidad para adentrarse en ella. Yo, por mi parte, jugaré la tercera entrega así como Andrómeda también, a pesar de las críticas le tengo muchas ganas. Y luego claro, a esperar el próximo título de esta épica franquicia ya anunciado. ¡Cuantas ganas y cuanto futuro!

[h1]A shining monument to the time when Bioware made good games[/h1]

One of my all-time favourite games, I have played this title to death, sadly.

If you are looking for a good RPG and can look past the pretty bland combat, and graphics that weren't great when it came out 13+ years ago, then Mass Effect is [i]highly[/i] recommended.

Mass Effect's world creation, characters, and story pacing are all great, and the writing and tone are considerably less juvenile than most Bioware CRPGs. Sadly the series went downhill from here immediately, with Bioware commencing a run of underwhelming releases that continues to this day.

A remaster of the entire Mass Effect trilogy is due for release in early 2021, so consider waiting to see how well that is received before buying this version.

84451437.review:
(IF YOU ARE USING AN OLDER PC READ THIS:
 There is a known graphical glitch that changes all characters to black blobs for two missions, it does not Affect the game other than visually. You can fix this by editing a text file and is very easy:
1) Go to documents>bioware>mass effect>BIOInput (should open a text page)
2) Add "ConsoleKey=Tlde" under [Engine.Console] in the text page
3) When the glitch happens press the ~ Key and bring up the command console. 
4) In that console type: "viewmode unlit"
5) after the mission is over you can type "viewmode lit" in the console (or reset the game) to return the game to normal)

Overview: This game is the first in a very epic trilogy but that does not mean this game has no flaws, it's aged and it shows but the story is still excellent and the gameplay is still good enough.

Combat:
-The gunplay in this game is decent. if you played the original halo games I would say they both do the job with similar competency.
-Melee does things and exists, that's about it. (it is not OP like in Halo)
-Abilities in this game are the strongest in the series. Some of them do trivialize combat but not enough to really detract from the game

Story:
-The story is solid and well flushed out. Arguably one of the best I have seen.
-Characters are well done and actually feel like part of the story and not just "extras"

Other stuff:
-The side quests in this game are well, not great. If you do not want to grind through all the side quests you are not missing much from this game.
-The Mako Tank sucks to drive, it controls poorly and is largely used for the side quests. overall the combat in the Mako is tollerable on flat ground but garbage on hilly terrain.
-There are a number of glitches that exist in the game that can help you progress without having to "slog" through the game on a new game + save file (ie you can max out "paragon/renegade" stats by repeating a single conversation over which allows you to save some grinding)

It's good, but does not hold up the test of time. I went in with huge expectations based on what I had heard about how good the game was (so no nostalgia lenses), but was met with clunky combat, awkward npc/AI mechanics, and lifeless planets to explore. It was good and I completed it and all side quests. The main story quests were all great and fleshed out and the storyline was fun and the dialogue was great especially when sheppard's dialogue choice isn't always as expected.

Once learning, upon doing research, that shotguns are the best until late game and work at a huge distance, combat encounters improved a ton. But for real...why have assault rifles with 0 accuracy. Suffers from overfilled inventory and not having all your skills until late in the game so you barely get to have fun with them. 

Also the beginning of the game had a character creator, I wanted to play sheppard so I did not touch it, turns out that it was actually just choosing gender, backstory, and class.

For a new player I recommend creating a character, using shotguns initially, trying to control the AI's skills but don't worry about the buggy movement, focusing on the main story and some side quests, but don't waste your time exploring the empty planets, also maybe mod the game to have unlimited inventory. I'd say 4-5 hours of my playtime was spent managing inventory, for real. Play it knowing that it is a clunky classic. Apparently ME2 is supposed to be fantastic, so if you plan on playing that, then play this first to help build your world with the choices you make.

84082476.review:
The only mass effect game that actually had the scope right. The only mass effect game that i can call great. After playing the mass effect trilogy including andromeda,this game is my favourite one among all. This game had best concept/ideas and imo best gameplay too. The lore is also very deep on this game compared to any other mass effect game. Imo this the only mass effect game that actually did sci-fi game concept right.
Be aware the review might contain spoilers.
GAMEPLAY:
------------
Mass effect is a light rpg with tactial action shooter elements. Lets start with the first thing a player is allowed to give their input to on the game, the dialogues. The Dialogue system in this game is done very well. I would say its the best among all mass effect games. This game has the least amount of auto dialogues compared to other games. Dialogue choices are also done perfectly. I actually felt like i was making choices that shaped the galaxy. Yes it is true not all the choices affects the end but you can see the impact of your choices on characters. And yes some choices are straight up illusion of choice which all mass effect games have,but this one had the strongest of all. You actually had the ability to say whatever you wanted even if it might not have affected the plot. You were given the freedom to shape your character however you want,the feeling which other games failed to make me feel like. There is also charm and intimidation on player stats which directly affects on what you can say on dialogues. Charm for more charamastic dialogues aka paragon and intimidation for rough n tough dialogues aka renegade. This added the sense of tacticallity and player freedom even on what the character can say. Again something other games totally axed. You also get to choose your characters backstory and origin. And the world reacts accordingly and dialogues are also played out according to what origin and backstory you choose. Player freedom in this game is amazing.
Now lets talk about combat. Combat can be dived into two sections: solo combat and squad combat. Both are equally detailed.
 Solo combat in this game is very engaging and actually requires you to use the abilities given to you thoughtfully. Unlike other games where all you do is mindlessly shoot things. The Combat is very tactical which seperates itself from just a cover shooter. Ai in combat is also very smart. You can't just stay in cover and be safe,if you stay in cover for too long enemies actually come and attack you from front. This forces you to actually plan your combat strategy rather then just shooting whatever you see. The indepth player stats also add to that layer of tacticality,you can't just get most expensive armour and call it a day. You actually have to upgrade your amour stats in order to have proper defensive play. I also personally liked the overheat feature which most people seem to hate. I think the overheat feature actually forced player to take it slow and not fire mindlessly,again added more tacticallity to the game,made it trial and error which i personally enjoyed.
Squad combat is also best in this game. Its the one that gives most control to the player instead of holding your hand and taking away most control like other games. You can give commands such as move,hold postion,attack,rally and also mix those commands to direct squad mates however you like. Another thing which next titles failed to achieve. You can also customise your squad mates armour and even squad mates have indepth stats system. Which allows player to decide what kind of playstyle squad mate goes with. The amount of player freedom this game has is mental and its honestly one of my favourite thing about this game.
Now lets talk about exploration+side content,mission/level design.
Exploration in this game is something that is heavily criticized,but personally i thought it was fine and i actually enjoyed it for most cases. Yes it did have its flaws and starts to feel bit repetitive after a while but i enjoyed the sense of galaxy exploration it gave. And all planets actually have purpose to exist for side content or collectables,it wasn't clusterf*ck like andromeda. Side content is what makes those planets even more interesting to explore,most side content actually has interesting story/lore behind them. Except few where all you do is shoot things mostly n7 ones that are bad. Its not flawless but i didn't find it bad either. One thing to keep in mind exploration was never forced on player and also never interfered with main missions it was always there as an option.Shame sequels never managed to make exploration reach its full potential
Mission design is where mass effect is at its peak. Every single area of a mission actually have purpose to exist and missions are also not boring/linear at the same time. It's open ended while also not losing any focus or quality. Missions can end in different ways,different outcomes use diffeeent areas of the missions. World and characters even reacts on which order you did the main missions in. For example i went to the attacked colony feros at last so they were pissed i was late,liara gets pissed if you go to rescue her at last. This acknowledgement of player's action from world is fantastic and i loved it.
Now i will go over few more minor things i liked. Inventory system was good except the annoying loot system menu,variety of weapon mods/accessories,player customization and squad customization was also good.
Overall i loved mass effect's gameplay because of how open ended it is without losing focus and also because of how much player freedom it gives.
Story:
------
Lore of mass effect is one of the most detailed lore i have ever seen. The amount of backstories it has just for the sake of world building is mind blowing. This is the only mass effect that actually does the sci-fi/space opera fiction right. The World is believable,mysterious,unpredictable and also familiar all at the same time. There are also sub plots going on in the world such as genophage,quarian and geth conflict all this just to make player feel part of the world. And it does it so well.
Plot starts out simple with our hero shepard going to an attacked colony then finding out about rogue spectre. Then becoming first human spectre himself. Then it gets complicated when its revealed main villain is an ancient ai civilization called repears. The ending to this game is also very satisfying
Overall story and world of mass effect is something i adore now because of how detailed it is.
CONCLUSION:
--------------
Overall mass effect is a great game with its indepth rpg elements,tactical action shooter gameplay and absolute player freedom over things compared to other ones in the series. Story and lore is also something that is very detailed to a point it actually makes you feel like you are part of the world. All those things combined imo makes it the best mass effect game.

este juego cuenta solo con un modo historia, que debo decir que me a encantado!, sin duda de los mejores juegos que e jugado y mira que jugue bastantes. su historia es muy buena, transmite un monton de sentimientos como; miedo, esperanza, tristeza, tension y un monton mas, no quiero hablar mucho por que arruinaria la experiencia.
el personaje principal es John Shepard tambien puedes crear tu propio personaje y cambiarle de sexo, pero si quieres jugar de manera "canonica" debes jugar con el personaje que te propone el propio juego. podremos elegir clase para nuestro personaje tales como, soldado, mecanico, soldado biotico y otros mas, tambien cuenta con un sistema de habilidades que haran que nuestro personaje se especialize en una rama u otra.
en el gameplay es frenetico y de accion podremos utilizar varias armas que son: un rifle de asalto, una escopeta, una pistola, un rifle francotirador y granadas, lo que me encanta de los combates es porder cubrirte, me refiero a que si corremos hacia un muro nuestro personaje se cubrira y podremos disparar mientras estamos a cubierto,
