83685189.review:
[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
Humanity has become an interstellar species after finding and activating an alien portal. There are many other alien species in the galaxy and activating that portal did not please many. Ironically, we are the galaxy's best hope in preventing a plot that will wipe out all live in the entire galaxy.

[H1]The good[/H1]
For a game that is now 14 years old it still holds pretty well for the storytelling. Having completed ME1 in 2020 felt like reading an interactive book, with intricate world building and character development. It is not like many Bethesda games where lore is just dumped in many books spread around the world and after the 10th book you think: "yes whatever". Instead, the lore is woven through all interactions and is carefully balanced. You always long for more, instead of getting bored with it.

I played mostly the good guy (called Paragon in ME1) and most choices seem to make sense. Like many of the older Bioware games there are multiple ways to finding and solving quests and it is this part that make this a really good game. I enjoyed the voice acting of my companions and they grew on me as I progressed. Be aware that you will play this game mainly for the dialogues so it is text heavy; at any time you can skip it but you will miss out the best of the game.
 
[H1]The not so good[/H1]
The game is from 2007 and unless you really would like to relive that time in terms of graphics and videos, I would strongly recommend to use at least a few mods to make the game feel and play a lot better. Find the hard work of fans at [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/] Nexus Mods [/url]. Still you will notice many decisions in level design that probably had to be put in place to make it run on 2007 machines: like the endless amount of elevators, 90 degree corners and walls covering up half of a level but that's ok: back in 2007 even with this I couldn't play it well as my PC was just too slow.

The inventory system is atrocious: even though it's an old game something like Diablo 1 or 2 had a better visual system where the items made a lot of sense. Just using a text-based system is very 1995.

The sound effects and music aren't so great - it's just serviceable and some of the songs are quite depressing.

The combat is just plain horrible: I played as an infiltrator/ commando but many times I had to fall back on my gun as that was the easiest way to dispose of the enemies. In general, the tactics of the brain-dead AI is just to swarm you: this got me killed a lot the first two times and then I realized the weakness and found a way to beat them without much trouble. Unfortunately, it is the same of my companions: while I love the interaction, they are just fodder in combat: merely there to distract while not being effective at all for most of the times. I couldn't help comparing it to a game like XCOM and it may have been a better solution to not make battles real-time but instead turn based so the player would not suffer so much of the bad AI.

The side quests in general felt poorly developed and pale in comparison to the main story. I did a few but they all felt like: "go to this system, land on this generic planet where we just changed the colour scheme and enter one of the two or three generic bases and kill everything or find an item". Finishing them was also not rewarding at all (you just get a text screen), except for one where you were able to get a specialized character class (but then again this did not make sense to me at all). 

The graphics settings are a bit strange: I thought I could only play up to 1280x1024 but then on closer inspection there are arrows that bring up all HD resolutions as well. 

I disliked the MAKO (your vehicle) for its horrible physics and that together with the poor level design on generic planets where you literally have to drive over mountains made it not a good experience.

[H1]Summary[/H1]
You can see that I name quite a few things that aren't that good. Does the good outweigh all of that? Well, yes it does. If you enjoy good story telling then this is still a game to get 14 or 15 years later. There will be a remaster coming out in 2021 but you don't have to wait for that IMHO. With the help of dedicated fans, the game still looks very good and despite its flaws the story is what kept me going. The layers of the world, the large amount of alien races and the mystery slowly reveals themselves to you. And this is actually interesting: I stopped playing AC Odyssey as I was bored and the story was not able to keep my attention - in the end you have this beautiful world that feels empty. With ME it is the opposite: yes, there are many flaws and the game is old but the story is what keeps it alive and fresh. I can understand now why people return to this game or finish it multiple times. 

It's a classic game and most likely one of the last true Bioware gems before it all went south (which is such a shame as I used to be a huge fan ever since BG1). Just for that reason alone anyone with an interest in sci-fi action/RPG should play this game at least once. I got the game in 2008 but I was not able to play it on my computer back then. I then lost the copy and it was not until now (2020/2021) that I finally manage to play it. I enjoyed the game and I'm looking forward in playing the other ME games after this one.

83667498.review:
Great storyline, interesting character development and the graphics hold well up to this day (not as good as the graphics from present games, but even so it holds well enough). I'm sure the remastered edition will improve, at least, in the last aspect. So, if you're the kind of person who wants to play with higher graph specs, just wait a little. It's coming up in 2021.

The only thing I didn't enjoy as much is the exploration with the Mako. It becomes almost an obligation to explore the planets to complete side-quests like picking up minerals, metals, etc. I'm not against it, but it forces you to explore every planet instead of being a nice option for whoever likes exploration. Besides, if you don't go exploring and don't do the side-quests, it can be harder to get a good-enough level for the main missions. Half the exploration for me was already too much. 
The exploration part per se is not that bad. When I played ME Andromeda, exploration was longer, for example, but it was also nice from time to time (specially considering the views). However, for me it was the same as it has been with ME1, I would've liked less exploration and grinding side-quests. I'd rather talk to someone and find their lost relative who will later be helping out in some other place. Go into their story a bit rather than go looking for any plant/mineral/whatever that has no special purpose apart from completing a collection that has no use or implication later on at any level. Getting a badge for completing this kind of missions doesn't feel good enough for me if there's no effect at all in the game story, character interactions or object/building changes. Not that I don't like hearing the "news" while in the elevator, but I also like more visible implications.

Personally, I'd rather focus on the story, character development and seeing the consequences of your own choices. That's what I liked the most about this game. Your actions have implications in the world around you and you can see those along the game. That part was awesome! But that's just personal taste. 

Overall, the game is great up to this day and I highly recommend it. For those of you who like good choice-driven stories, and also exploration, I'm sure you'll love it even more than I did :)

Anyways, loved the story! Happy new year to everyone <3

83632392.review:
I'm a little late to the party but, playing Mass Effect for the first time in 2020 I can see why the game was heralded as a big deal upon release and spawned a powerful franchise that continues on all these years later.

Immersion is the name of the game here. This is pure sci-fi bliss. So much love and care went into crafting the futuristic world. Exploring the citadel, I moved between locales that evoked the best of 80's space cinema, into areas that represented what my imagination might conjure in the heat of a laser tag battle and then on into locations that felt like a matured version of Disney's Tomorrowland. Sometimes they felt like all three at once! Such detail! I could touch the concrete overpass, feel the wind drifting by in the starry night, tousling my hair, see myself awash in neon lights. I wasn't playing a game. I was really there!!

The mood is enhanced by a masterfully crafted score. Synth tones and digital percussion blend to inject you with the suspense, mystery and wonder that would await you in a romanticized future.

The world building is easily one of the best of any game I have ever experienced.

Story is deep and engaging. Combat can be a little clunky on PC due to the controls and lack of console controller support options, but the progression system is deeply rewarding. The player agency provided by dialog and behavior choices is really special. This is one of the few games I have played that offer dialog response choices that feel natural, rather than forced.

Overall an amazing game, and one that was released way ahead of it's time. Looking forward to part 2!

Mass Effect is a classic role-playing game developed by Bioware.

The action begins in the year 2183. 35 years earlier, mankind had discovered artifacts and ruins on Mars of the Protheans, an apparently extinct but technologically extremely advanced civilization. After examining and deciphering the prosthetic artifacts, humans were finally able to develop space propulsion systems faster than light and also discovered the mass portals that allow them to travel quickly to other planetary systems. Shortly afterwards, numerous human colonies were established within the Milky Way.

In 2157 humans first encountered an intelligent alien species, the turians. The so-called First Contact War broke out, but it ended shortly afterwards on the intervention of the Citadel Council. The Citadel is a space station in the Serpent Nebula that serves as the seat of an intergalactic world government. The most influential species, asari, turians and salarians, are represented with their own councilors in the Citadel Council, less influential species usually try to protect their interests through a message on the Citadel. Humanity then also sends its own ambassador and tries to integrate itself peacefully into intergalactic society. But since the people belong to the most rapidly expanding and aspiring peoples of the Citadel, the turians in particular encounter them with a certain distrust.

An unknown Prothean artifact was found on the human colony of Eden Prime in 2183. The player character Commander Shepard, who can be male or female, is a soldier on a secret mission of the Citadel Council on board a frigate prototype called "SSV Normandy", a spaceship of the human alliance, to recover the artifact. In addition to the recovery, the mission also serves the purpose of examining Shepard as a possible candidate for the Citadel special forces of the Specters (Special Tactics and Reconnaissance). Members of this unit are elite soldiers whose job it is to maintain peace and stability in the galaxy. They have special powers and a high reputation, only they have to justify themselves before the Citadel Council, from which they can also receive orders. The alliance hopes to gain significance among the Citadel peoples by accepting a person in the special unit for the first time.

Upon arrival of the Normandy, however, Eden Prime is attacked by the geth led by the turian and longtime Specters Saren, who is trying to get the artifact into his possession. The geth are a cybernetic race created as servants by the quarians who turned against their creators and exiled them. Shepard and his unit can prevent them from stealing the artifact, but it destroys itself when Shepard comes too close to him. Visions burn into his consciousness that herald the destruction of planets and all of the inhabitants living on them. As the game progresses, these turn out to be a warning to the Protheans against the attacks of a technically advanced race known only as "the Reaper".

- Minimap immediately shows all target areas on planets
- Vehicle cannot be upgraded
- Party members cannot be positioned individually in a fight and behave stupidly

[h1] Information / Review Deutsch [/h1]

Mass Effect ist ein klassisches Rollenspiel, welches von Bioware entwickelt wurde. 

[h1] Gameplay / Geschichte [/h1]

Die Handlung beginnt im Jahr 2183. 35 Jahre zuvor hatte die Menschheit auf dem Mars Artefakte und Ruinen der Protheaner, einer offenbar ausgestorbenen, aber technologisch extrem weit fortgeschrittenen Zivilisation, entdeckt. Nach der Untersuchung und Entschlüsselung der protheanischen Artefakte konnten die Menschen schließlich Raumfahrtantriebe mit Überlichtgeschwindigkeit entwickeln und entdeckten auch die Massenportale, mit denen sie schnell in andere Planetensysteme reisen können. Kurz darauf wurden zahlreiche menschliche Kolonien innerhalb der Milchstraße errichtet.

Im Jahr 2157 trafen Menschen erstmals auf eine intelligente außerirdische Spezies, die Turianer. Es kam zum sogenannten Erstkontaktkrieg, der jedoch kurz darauf auf Intervention des Citadel-Rats beendet wird. Die Citadel ist eine Raumstation im Serpent-Nebel, die als Sitz einer intergalaktischen Weltregierung dient. Die einflussreichsten Spezies, Asari, Turianer und Salarianer, sind mit einem eigenen Ratsherren im Citadel-Rat vertreten, weniger einflussreiche Spezies versuchen in der Regel ihre Interessen durch eine Botschaft auf der Citadel wahren zu lassen. Die Menschheit entsendet daraufhin ebenfalls einen eigenen Botschafter und versucht sich in die intergalaktische Gesellschaft friedlich zu integrieren. Da die Menschen aber zu den am stärksten expandierenden und aufstrebendsten Völkern der Citadel gehören, begegnen ihnen insbesondere die Turianer mit einem gewissen Misstrauen. 

Auf der menschlichen Kolonie Eden Prime wird im Jahr 2183 ein unbekanntes Artefakt der Protheaner gefunden. Der Spielercharakter Commander Shepard, der wahlweise männlich oder weiblich sein kann, befindet sich als Soldat in geheimer Mission des Citadel-Rates an Bord eines Fregattenprototyps genannt „SSV Normandy“, ein Raumschiff der menschlichen Allianz, um das Artefakt zu bergen. Die Mission dient neben der Bergung auch dem Ziel, Shepard als möglichen Kandidaten für die Citadel-Spezialeinheit der Spectres (Special Tactics and Reconnaissance) zu prüfen. Mitglieder dieser Einheit sind Elitesoldaten, deren Aufgabe darin besteht, Frieden und Stabilität in der Galaxie zu wahren. Sie verfügen über besondere Vollmachten und ein hohes Ansehen, einzig vor dem Citadel-Rat müssen sie sich rechtfertigen, von dem sie ebenfalls Aufträge erhalten können. Durch die erstmalige Aufnahme eines Menschen in die Spezialeinheit erhofft sich die Allianz einen Bedeutungszuwachs unter den Citadel-Völkern.

Bei Ankunft der Normandy wird Eden Prime jedoch von den Geth unter der Führung des Turianers und langjährigen Spectres Saren angegriffen, welcher versucht, das Artefakt in seinen Besitz zu bringen. Die Geth sind eine vom Volk der Quarianer als Diener erschaffene kybernetische Rasse, die sich gegen ihre Schöpfer wandten und diese ins Exil trieben. Shepard kann sie mit seiner Einheit zwar an der Entwendung des Artefakts hindern, doch zerstört sich dieses selbst, als Shepard ihm zu nahe kommt. Dabei brennen sich ihm Visionen ins Bewusstsein, die von der Zerstörung von Planeten und aller darauf lebenden Bewohner künden. Im Verlauf des Spiels stellen sich diese als Warnung der Protheaner vor den Angriffen einer technisch weit fortgeschrittenen Rasse, die nur als „die Reaper“ bezeichnet wird, heraus. 

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ glaubwürdiges SciFi-Universum
+ unheimlich große Spielwelt
+ gutes taktisches Kampfsystem
+ klasse Waffen- & Biotikeffekte
+ sehr stimmungsvoller Soundtrack
+ Entscheidungen mit Konsequenzen
+ Wiederspielwert dank hoher Levelbegrenzung (60) und alternativer Spielweisen (vorbildlich/skrupellos)
+ sehr gutes Kreaturendesign der Gegner

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

- zu wenig Leben in der Stadt und Ansprechpartner in den beiden Bars
- Minimap zeigt auf Planeten sofort alle Zielgebiete an 
- Fahrzeug lässt sich nicht aufrüsten
- Partymitglieder lassen sich im Kampf nicht einzeln postieren und verhalten sich dämlich

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Mass Effect bietet dir ein ScFi-Abenteuer, welches du nicht mehr vergessen wirst, dieses ist von moralischen und emotionalen Konflikten geprägt. Klare Kaufempfehlung.

Picked this game up as part of the Winter Sale (2020) as over the years a lot of friends had recommended the series to me over the years

On the surface, the game is a typical 2000 era RPG: Space, aliens, beacons, betrayal. I get the feeling that most people follow the series for the story, which I found to be pretty compelling even if it's a bit dated because it follows the same script a lot of games of that era did.

The game itself was very glitchy, which I expected but took me out of the moment a great deal. At one point a character was remarking on how marvelous something looked, and it was just a huge black bar for me. Also fell *through* a couple elevators.  Should've just played on console lol.

It's a lot of fun though, once you figure out how the leveling and abilities work you can really get the ball rolling. The combat system of telling your team what to do every step of the way or else they stand and get pelted by rockets left much to be desired....

anyway, I enjoyed it enough to try Mass Effect 2. Will be interesting to see how the choices I made in the first effect the second.

Mass Effect is a phenomenal RPG. YOU are the hero of the story. A huge threat of ancient machinery is threatening all lives in the galaxy. During your journey, you will meet those who are loyal and will take a stand with you during these tough times. A small glimmer of hope that the galaxy can win is what will motivate you to rise up and fight.

Saren was an amazing villain as he constantly challenges your mindset about the fight against the Reapers. I also personally love the heavy exploration and customization aspect of the first one, though it might not be your cup of tea. My first entry was to the franchise was with Mass Effect 3 but I wanted to experience the story that started it all. People seem to give less credit to the first one because of some game mechanics that they find confusing.

Give this game a chance, you won't regret it.

83207076.review:
Up until I first played Mass Effect, I quit whenever games got hard. This was the first game where I was so determined to see the whole story, I could make myself keep pushing through no matter how many times I died (and I died a lot). Every time I wanted to give up I'd say to myself "Do you want to kiss the alien?? Yes?? Then try again!" 

And I have kissed so many aliens.

I bought the entire series for Xbox and for PC, and when the remastered version comes out, I'm buying it again. 

Mass Effect 1 is the best for customization. It has the widest variety of dialogue options per conversation. The weapons, armor, and level up system allows you to fine-tune your stats with precision. Weapons using a cool-down timer instead of finite ammunition changes the flow of combat in very interesting ways. It also has the most feet-on-the-ground exploration, and so many sidequests that (despite about 300 hours of gameplay between the two systems) I still haven't found them all. And some of the sidequests are changed by the backgrounds you choose.

Downsides: the sheer volume of the game can feel overwhelming sometimes. If you don't enjoy managing armor and weapon stats, having to do it for your companions can feel tedious. Combat can feel slow, and special attacks lack the flair the later games provide. (Biotics in particular feel sort of floaty, making the target drift gently to the ground without much physical impact.)

I recommend this series to everyone, but specifically if you like RPGs, space operas, meaningful choices carrying across games, and having sex with hot aliens of various shapes and sizes.

82833293.review:
This is my favourite game of all time so I had to refrain in giving it a 10, but still wanted to give it a vote that matched my enthusiasm. I know, today we are in 2020 and the game play is a little outdated, it's more of a vintage RPG game play, however, for being a 2007 game the graphics still hold up pretty well, with facial animation that, back in the day, made us all excited and left us in awe (that's why Andromeda was such a let down as well). This game is a good representation of what Bioware was capable of doing and their strength in story telling. Every choice matters and it impacts your characters. Yes, there is a binary way of playing, either you are a renegade or a paragon and to unlock certain options you will have to lean more in one direction that the other and vicecersa. This is all because of the kind of story they wanted to tell and limitations of the time.
The combat is not the best, but that was never the point of this game, it's a story driven RPG that is meant to have you connect with your team and travel the galaxy in order to find a way to defeat the Reapers (the baddies). I replayed it earlier this year and enjoyed it as if it were my first time.
Because my console is old (and it is a big game) it's very glitchy, that's why I would suggest to save often and right before fights.
Even though the combat is meh, there are some aspects that I wish had been transferred in the sequels (I'll review the other 2 as well and explain why there), like the diversity in approach and tension that the different attackers approach you. Because the shooting is so basic and simple, if you are not much of a shooter game person, it won't be a problem, it will actually help you out in getting into them as it did with me.
As I mentioned you will be travelling the galaxy, which means you will land on planets for side missions and you will have a chance to use the infamous MAKO. I personally grew to love driven it; you can defy the laws of physics with it, you'll be wanting to throw the controller at the tv or you can challenge yourself in accomplishing this extra challenge the game throws at you lol I now laugh at it and if you go on the internet to watch some videos you will witness the comedy of it all.
This is definitely a game everyone needs to experience at least once. the remaster has been announced for 2021 and I can't wait to see how they update this chapter (I am terrified and exhilarated at the same time).

82221244.review: I originally played this on my PS3 but now that I'm able to play on steam and take my laptop on the go. I can enjoy the series once again, still getting use to keyboard controls. 10/10 recommend!!! If you want the DLC then you're going to have to go the EA website to download the DLC!! For some reason after a few tries of trying the pinnacle station the game will freeze during the loading screen. I would just save after completing one and then restarting it if it freezes. Black pixels glitch/bug on Noveria: Peak 15 and also on Illos, I had to add in the ~ command by going to Documents > Bioware > Mass Effect > Config >BIOInput. Slide down until you find [Engine.Console] right underneath it add ConsoleKey=tilde and save and close. (if you're not confident with this copy/save the entire document onto word doc or any other place to save it just in case) and type in "viewmode unlit" then enter to turn it off press command key ~ and "viewmode lit" while the black pixels are gone the game seems to have brighter settings. It'll be okay its better than black block pixels and also  when you enter the elevator you'll get stuck. Two ways to fix this; First is to save before you enter the elevator and if you get stuck then reload until it works but that takes a while. Second is to use the same ~ command and type "walk in" then enter and it will let you walk around freely and then it will work and get the elevator working again.

81837599.review:
Lo primero que tengo que decir es que como persona con una discapacidad visual agradezco MUCHÏSIMO, la opción de "ayuda de apuntado" esa opción que puedes activar y lo único que hace es poner sobre los enemigos un triangulo de color rojo (ojala hicieran esto mismo en más juegos para 1 jugador, incluso para los Online estaría bien para ayudar a la gente que como yo no ve un pimiento). Esto me a ayudado muchísimo a la hora de jugar y ver a los enemigos en situaciones donde me hubiera costado mucho localizarlos.

Ahora... ¿que tal es Mass Effect?, a mi me a parecido un gran juego, una historia que te atrapará, poder responder a tu gusto a cada uno de los NPC´S y ser Virtuoso o Rebelde es un puntazo (además de que según tus respuestas hay secuencias bastante interesantes e incluso divertidas). 

Misiones principales y secundarias interesantes, leyendo algunas reseñas me encontré con gente que decía que las misiones secundarias se hacen repetitivas, a estos les pregunto ¿Y que te esperas en un RPG Clásico, misiones de persecución al estilo GTA?, tal vez no son la gran cosa, pero tiene fragmentos de la historia muy interesantes, donde conocerás algunos detalles del universo en el que te encuentras (según mi criterio y como jugador ya desde hace años siempre es interesante y divertido obtener datos del mundo que las desarrolladoras se han molestado en crear para nosotros, así que todo lo que proporcione información o alargar el videojuego de forma divertida e interesante es bueno, ¡¡OJO!! he dicho de forma interesante, no coleccionables ridículos como hay en algunos juegos que luego no sirven para nada), además de que si las haces conseguirás una burrada de objetos que te ayudaran durante la aventura principal.

Lo que a mi me a sacado un poco de quicio, a sido el manejo del Coche XD, para ser un "todo terreno espacial" hay zonas donde te cuesta un poco acceder (bueno también puede ser culpa mía por que me encanta "romper el juego" y tratar de escalar montañas buscando atajos en vez de ir por donde se supone que hay que ir), aunque es divertido ver como te caes de una montaña rodando y no pasa nada XD. 

En fin para no andarme por las ramas ni hacer spoiler de ningún tipo, definitivamente si aun no as comprado este juego... ya vas buscando el modo de comprarlo, por que es una joya.

81253024.review:
[h1]Las aventuras del comandante Shepard pt. 1[/h1]

Todo comienza con una supuesta mision de vuelo de la alianza humana para probar su nave estrella, la Normandia, pero el comandante y su tripulacioon empieza a sospechar cuando se les asigna un Espectro a la tripulacion sin mucha informacion por parte del oficial al mando. Llegados a cierto punto se nos revela que en realidad estan en una mision para ayudar al Consejo de la Ciudadela a recuperar una baliza proteana en Eden Prime y que dicho espectro esta ahi para asegurar el exito de la mision y al mismo tiempo, evaluar a Shepard para ingresarlo en las filas de los espectros.

El juego en si es un TPS-RPG de aventura espacial con una galaxia que tiene varios sistemas solares con sus respectivos planetas, algunos de ellos explorables mediante un analisis directo de la nave y otros con los pies en tierra con nuestro peloton y nuestro vehiculo.
En primer lugar el vehiculo se controla muy mal, pero es tan malo que resulta divertido verlo volar por los aires y casi no hacerse daño. Este mismo cuenta con un cañon y una gatling para el combate que funcionan similar a las armas normales.

En segundo lugar vas a contar con un peloton de maximo 2 personajes y tu personaje principal con distintos tipos de habilidades y clases. En este punto es donde mas falla el juego en mi opinion porque si no llevas personajes con habilidades de decodificacion y electronica, eso convierte a Keidan en tu compañero fundamental durante toda la historia porque tiene las 2 juntas.
Aparte de las habilidades standart, cada personaje tendra una habilidad especial en base a su rango (si se trata de humanos) o de su raza si se trata de aliens.
En el apartado de armas tendremos 4 tipos: pistolas, fusil de asalto, escopetas y rifles de francotirador. Cada una ellas pueden ser usadas con el personaje principal pero el resto de tus aliados deberan tener el entrenamiento requerido para usar bien cada tipo de arma y algunos siquiera cuentan con dichos entrenamientos.
Las armas no utilizan municion sino un sistema de calor que hace que regules el dedo a la hora de disparar, basicamente si te pasas disparando vas a tener un cooldown para poder volver a disparar, y creo que no funciona cambiar entre las armas.

Con respecto a la IA tanto de aliados como de enemigos, debo decir que es casi un chiste, dado que los enemigos siempre van a correr hacia vos y en fila para que no tengas ni que moverte a la hora de dispararles y los aliados donde mas balas haya, hacia ahi iran y bien felices con esto, ni dandole ordenes de movimiento podia hacer que se pongan a cobertura solo se paraban en el lugar y se quedaban ahi mirando como si nada pasara. Pero de eso voy a hablar a continuacion.
Porque con respecto a la interfaz de inventario y el hud son donde el juego mas hace notar su edad, son muy viejos y mal pensados. el inventario permite un maximo de 150 objetos entre armas, armaduras y mejoras, y el problema no es que se quede corto sino que tenes una opcion, hacerlas omnigel que se utiliza para abrir cerraduras al instante, pero que pasa no podes convertir mas de a una por ves y se vuelve muy tedioso tener que hacerlo una por una con un maximo de 999 del mismo.
Y lo mejor de todo esto el hud para dar ordenes al peloton, gracias a dios tiene un sistema para que los aliados usen sus habilidades automaticamente, pero que sino nadie las usaria, para usar una de ellas tendremos que entrar a dicha interfaz y desde ahi dar la orden de la habilidad que queres usar pero si o si tenes que tener apuntado el personaje que queres como objetivo porque una vez que entremos no podremos mover la camara y es una molestia infernal.
Esta interfaz tambien sirve para cambiar las armas de todo el peloton y para armar un barra de accesos directos a las habilidades de Shepard.

Ahora con la exploracion planetaria y los mapas, para los planetas que podemos desembarcar y no sean principales, tendremos como primer encuentro, aunque no pasara en todos, un aviso de comunicacion para informarnos de una mision secundaria en el planeta o sistema, puede que la mision sea de varios planetas e incluso sistemas pero lo mejor es que nunca vas a tener que regresar a ningun lado para entregarla, cuando llegas al final de la mision y la completes bien o mal, recibiras otra llamada con el informe de situacion y unas palabras del que la envie para agradecerte o regañarte por no hacerlo bien.
Los planetas que permiten el desembarco van a ser de mundo abierto con varios puntos de interes y metales para descubrir, sirven como una especie de coleccionable y fuente de ingresos de dinero.
Ahora bien los mapeados de interiores son todos exactamente iguales con detalles diferenciales en base al tipo de fauna o atmosfera que se encuentre en el planeta.

Algo que no se si esta bueno o malo, pero a mi me parecio bastante bueno, es que no haya que lootear cuerpos, todo se agrega automaticamente al inventario, y dado que hay muchos enemigos en los mapas es un punto muy a favor.



Para ser un titulo que tiene ya 12 años, me sorprendio para bien, quizas no sea la mejor jugabilidad del mundo ni los mejores graficos, pero la historia es interesante y te incita a jugar mas y avanzar. Lo unico que te frena un poco es lo repetitivo que se vuelve a la hora de explorar y hacer todas las misiones secundarias porque vas a estar viendo todo el tiempo los mismos mapas y mismas situaciones una y otra vez. Asi y todo lo recomiendo porque como primer inicio de una trilogia esta mas que interesante y ya jugue un poco de Mass Effect 2 y los cambios son brutales tanto visualmente como jugables, no se si para bien o peor todavia pero ya lo averiguare.

81157772.review:
With ME Legendary edition rolling out next year, I feel the need to give this classic an extra thumbs up. Mass Effect has been around for ages, yet it is my hope the new edition will attract more (potentially younger) audience.
Strap down for the rough ride into the future, where aliens of all kinds roam the galaxy alongside with humans and where slapping omnigel on everything solves almost all of your problems. Create your very own Commander Shepard, assemble a crew of close friends, and embark on the quest of saving the world from the race of sentient machines. 
While the engine didn't age well compared to the later Frostbite, it still does the job after some getting used to. The graphics look impressive even today, and the story... well, if anything has been BioWare's specialty, it's certainly storytelling.
This game has formed a generation of sci-fi rpg players and breathed life into the previously overlooked genre. It is a special, unique experience for so many, with loving fan community staying active throughout the years. If you haven't gotten it yet, I strongly recommend you grab Mass Effect as soon as you can.
God bless the MAKO.

80268452.review:
I first played Mass Effect in the winter of 2012.  I had heard good things about it and gave it a go over Christmas Break during my sophomore year of college.  Early on, I loved the s*** out of it.  Nowadays...I still love the s*** out of it.  

I have played each of the main trilogy games about ten times, both on xbox and PC.  I am fond of each of the games, though in different ways and for different reasons.  Gun to my head, I would probably pick the first one as the best; yes, it's the clunkiest of the three, but it is also the most RPG of the three.  

If you are looking for a gameplay challenge, I recommend playing something else; I have beaten this game on the hardest difficulty without my main character firing a shot or using an offensive power (and I did every single side mission [I did not do Pinnacle Station] and took care of just about every enemy in the game).   In the course of that playthrough I died once.  It's not that I am amazing at the game; it is that once Shepard levels up enough, the combat is pretty trivial.  Still, I find the fighting enjoyable as there are many ways to approach fights and the biotic powers are particularly over the top.  

The soundtrack to this game is terrific.  

This game has a little Deus Ex in it, as it has some clunky mechanics; the inventory system has some annoying features; why can I not convert batches of items to omni-gel?  It still beats the system from the sequels that nerfed the hell out of your inventory.  

Another aspect of the game that draws the ire of some fans is the Mako, the tank you drive around that was removed in subsequent games.  I love the Mako.  Does it handle like the Possum Van from Red Green?  Yes.  Do the shields regenerate slower than old people f***?  Yes.  Occasionally glitch and fling itself airborne until it sustains sufficient damage to bring on a "Mission Failed" message?  Yep.  But I still love that vehicle; exploring planets and moons was instrumental to making the world seem huge and mysterious.  The fact that this sucker could climb 80 degree slopes only added to my affection for it.  

The characters are largely excellent and this game features the best antagonist of the series.  

I recommend this game very highly.

79748356.review:
Where it all began. A lot of people forget how many annoying bugs and problems this game has. I don't. 175 hours keeps it fresh in your memory. I can't stand the way Shepard inadvertently dodges behind objects you're to run past. All the freedom of movement in Andromeda made me forget how literally stuck to the ground you are in these games. It's not just Andromeda, even in the second and especially the third game, Shepard's movement is far more quick and nimble. Here it's like you have ridiculous sudden bursts of uncontrollable speed followed by jamming the sprint key, but moving like jello pudding on cement cobblestones. I imagine in the "real world" I probably would run out of adrenaline in a firefight with aliens and take a piss, but it's annoying in a game to die because you suddenly can't run away fast enough.  

Despite all that I still love this game. I hold my breath a little every time I hear the theme music play in the opening menu. That familiar tune. The one that pulls at you in some deep complicated emotional way. Movement and combat and inventory management all suck, but the story is so damn good. The twists and turns and the company you keep and the friends you make along the way. The game really does feel like a whole universe of characters and lore to learn about and explore. And it's fun knowing that both of its sequels really build on the story telling, character development, and world building. Decisions you make in this game really do carry over and have some impact on even the third game. There's no other series in gaming that's like that. B-movie scifi that's so epic in it's scope by the third game it seems almost ready to implode on itself with ridiculousness and yet it prevails somehow. It's not the overall plot and story about the threat to the galaxy, it's all the tiny little moments in between where you make your own dialogue choices and you chose one option over another and you build your Shepard your own way and by the end of it all it really feels like you had your own unique experience. It's all a clever illusion of course--given the limited amount of options, a significant percentage of other players had a similar experience, but it still works and I still like it. 

Andromeda's failure is all the more acute given just how impressive this whole series was and the fact that the developers already created a winning formula. The "save the galaxy" story isn't new and didn't really need better writing for the sake of all the little moments in between that make the magic. Still I feel like Andromeda is a better game if they made it like Mass Effect and not too open world-y like Inquisition. Inquisition was able to support the weight of a massive open world because of two huge prior games of successive lore. Hundreds of hours of lore, actually, and as such a good playthrough of any Dragon Age game took at least 80 to 100 hours. No Mass effect game ever lasted more that 40 hours and then suddenly with Andromeda they think they can support a brand new galaxy, devoid of lore with over 80 hours of boring unrelated crap. If all the content of Andromeda was edited down to fit the size of previous games, it would've been a hit, because they would've been able to fix all the issues that had at release; before release, and they would've probably delivered something like a better looking more fleshed out version of this game. But I digress. 

If you're looking to play it now, you might as well wait for the remasters next spring at time of this writing. But you should definitely play it. Forgive its flaws and immerse yourself in it's story. Play all three in a row and remember that experience, because you won't have it again.

79443702.review:
The game that started it all!

Personally, I have mixed feelings about the original Mass Effect (ME1). In short, the role-playing mechanics, plot, and world building in ME1 are top notch, but the shooter and exploration mechanics are thoroughly clunky.

Let's begin with the negatives.

The shooter mechanics in ME1 can vary from passable to horrendously clunky. In my first playthrough ever (I've played through the Mass Effect trilogy three times), I chose the "Infiltrator" class, which mixes strong tech abilities with long range combat (having masteries for pistols and sniper rifles). Bad choice! As it turns out, the game artificially makes your aim with the sniper rifle wobbly, and you can only fix this wobble by maxing out your sniper rifle mastery as quickly as possible. Who does that? If the accuracy mechanic had instead revolved around having high recoil issues at first, I'd understand, but instead I got the equivalent of Shepard fighting while heavily inebriated. Furthermore, because of the high cooldowns and the lack of combo mechanics you see in later games, ME1's combat ends up feeling very clunky and oddly paced. You also end up facing an overwhelming amount of geth (robots) throughout the game.

The exploration mechanics are also rough to deal with. Driving the Mako alone felt like the stuff of meme dreams, with its bizarre physics. Still, at least the Mako provides comic relief; on the other hand, the extremely long and tedious side-quests (gathering Matriarch Dilinaga's writings, identifying natural resources/ores, etc) set against the backdrop of entire worlds that seem to just be terrain maps with textures on top make for a boring experience, especially when those side-quests are actually relevant to plot threads in later games. The tedium of the exploration mechanics is the #1 reason why I often skip re-playing ME1 in my Mass Effect trilogy playthroughs (I opt to load older saves instead).

On to the positives, then!

The world-building of ME1 is *amazing.* Whether it's the collision of species and cultures at the Citadel or the extensive amount of information in the codex, ME1 delivers on the promise of a vibrant, lived-in galaxy. This is something you'll have to see for yourself, but on world-building alone ME1 is worth at least one playthrough. Salarians, turians, asari, krogan, geth, honestly, even just writing about it makes me want to dive right back in to the Mass Effect universe. Characters are informed by their backgrounds but quite often break the in-universe stereotypes built around them, giving them all a sense of realistic variation.

The plot of ME1 is also excellent; if it *somehow* hasn't been spoiled for you, then I would strongly suggest playing through it and uncovering the mysteries behind Saren's plot for yourself.

The roleplaying element of ME1 is also decent, but I would argue that it's not possible to really judge the roleplaying element on ME1 alone. Taken across the trilogy as a whole, the roleplaying is amazing (aside from the hiccup that was ME3's original ending). As far as ME1 alone goes, I feel like the original roleplaying system of ME1 feels aged compared to the systems we see in ME2 and ME3. Still, there are many decisions that you make in ME1 that you only see the fruits of in ME2 and ME3, and on that alone I would argue that if you are at all interested in playing through ME2 or ME3, you should start with ME1.

As a final note, femshep x Liara forever!

79133386.review:
Not the masterpiece people claim, but worth playing for the story (if 2 and 3 are as good).

I finally got around to playing Mass Effect for the first time in 2020, and actually finished it about two days after they announced the remaster.   As a long time sci-fi reader, the premise of Mass Effect has been one that I was excited by, but (at least in 2008) RPG's not being my thing, the game never really got to the top of my backlog until I finished KOTOR and figured I’d see what Bioware could do when not tied down by a licensed property.

The result is interesting, I disagree that Mass Effect is as good as many of the other reviews suggest, but then I've not played it multiple times over the last decade!   It certainly is a good game, and a game that does leave me wanting to play the sequel.   Ultimately though, I won’t be bothering with the DLC (available for free from EA’s site) as it’s the story that I want to continue, not the gameplay.
Graphically the game is nothing special, but it’s more than adequate, and I had no real bugs to speak of. Importantly (except for potato-head Captain Anderson) nothing stood out as particularly god-awful, which was nice given how Windows 10 can behave at times.    Sound wise, the game is excellent, with superb voice acting throughout, and none of the incidental sounds (shooting, shields etc.) being too grating. Music is serviceable – I didn’t get goosebumps when it surged for dramatic moments, but it wasn’t irritating either.

What the game does badly however is the actual gameplay. As a character-development RPG it struggles a bit: although the skill tree is extensive, I had loads of unspent points at the end of the game simply because I didn't need them.  In the end I spent some to max out charisma and intimidation in the expectation of an end-game debate-off, but that turned out to be unnecessary.    On the other hand, combat did feel more impactful than say KOTOR in that the illusion of skill-based shooting is maintained in Mass Effect and weapons usually seem to make contact, but don’t expect the quality of shooting seen in say Deus Ex Mankind Divided.  It is a shame then that the combat mostly feels rote – shooting is basically sniping in bursts with the assault rifle with virtually all the other guns (possible exception of the sniper rifle for a few select moments) being irrelevant.   Combat skills are utterly irrelevant, I only used one (resurrect downed members of the party) and only during the final battle - In the previous 25 hours of gameplay I never once needed to bother with the other combat skills!      Weapons and other equipment are mostly acquired through random drops (you can buy them from shops but honestly don't bother) and truthfully the effect was an experience more like Borderlands (looter/shooter with random weapon spawns) than Doom 2016 (defined guns with points adding new abilities).

Some odd things that did crop up, which I imagine are because of my play style and only playing through once: I occasionally came across containers I couldn’t hack due to low electronics skill, but it was never made clear if/how I could resolve that (my Shephard didn’t have the electronics skill); my companions never seemed to level, so I couldn’t improve them (why give me heavy Turian armor if my Turian companion can never take above light armor?).    My sense on these is that there was some aspect of the tutorial that I managed to miss, but again, if I can complete the game without having to level the companions, maybe it simply doesn’t matter?

All of the above complaints are irrelevant however, because you're here for the story and the story does deliver (even if it does feel a bit like one long cutscene at times).   The overarching premise being Humanity is a newcomer to the galactic stage and is trying to prove that it is ready for a seat at the adult’s table.   Meanwhile a villain is working to unleash doom on the entire galaxy.    The story then is not ‘hard sci-fi’, but Bioware proved they can do space-opera with KOTOR and this is good space opera.    The evil menace treads dangerously close at times to Star Control 3 (with the big reveal in particular making me sigh at the similarity), but in fairness, I think the telling of the story is better here.   I can recommend the game based purely on this story and presentation alone.
What does stand out though is that the game expects certain things to happen, and thus when it makes these assumptions it can be jarring.    I spent the first half or so the game taking Wrex on every mission, the friendly walking shark-man was great in a fight and his snarky comments were continually amusing.    Until the game decided that he needed to be removed (one way or another, for story reasons), and for better or worse, my dialogue choices meant the irritating human female companion murdered him.   The irritating human companion that I hadn’t had any interaction with since meeting her in the first mission...   When we were back on the ship the game decided that there was obviously chemistry between us and we were set up to kiss.  Fortunately, a cliché interruption saved the day, but in another scene later I had to carefully navigate to delay having sex with this character I actively disliked.   Now I can enjoy the ‘got to bang ‘em all’ mini-games in the Witcher and the like, but in a story driven game I would prefer to ‘want’ to collect the card, and frankly the irritating woman I barely know who just murdered my best (man-shark) friend isn’t someone I want to collect.
The game also struggles with various beats where choices that feel wrong – e.g. what feels like a polite ‘no’ results in an aggressive ‘get lost’ response; or worse, (as with the love interest above) the choice on screen has the exact opposite meaning to the one the player says out loud.   My favorite example of this being the final choice in the game where the ‘it’s not over yet’ option had my character practically yell ‘I’ll do it myself then’ before storming off like a petulant child.  For the most part these moments are not impactful, and I recall reading complaints about this back when the game came out, so hopefully ME2 is better.   

The overall result then, and a recommendation – do play this game, if you are at all interested in story-driven gaming then Mass Effect is good, if you’re also a fan of science fiction, then it’s very good.   It will not have you feel like Captain Kirk (play 25th anniversary), nor is it a great shooting game (just play Doom 2016), nor is it a touchpoint that redefined the entire genre of RPG’s.  There are more intelligent RPGs out there, ones with better combat, and even some with better stories.  However, there are few games that do all of those things well, along with wonderful voice acting and some serviceable combat along the way.

Mainly of the memes and about the dashing Commander Shepard who would seduce all sorts of gratuitously sexy aliens and what not. Monótono y repetitivo tanto en la jugabilidad, como en la exploración y el desarrollo narrativo. El inventario y la conducción o están rotos o simplemente son un asco, el combate se vuelve aburrido en muy poco tiempo y ningún personaje -a excepción de Garrus y Wrex- llega a importarte lo más mínimo. Además, algunos escenarios están tan poco inspirados que dan risa, siendo la mayoría de las estaciones espaciales un conjunto de pasillos y ascensores o en el caso de los planetas; espacios abiertos áridos y desérticos.

Lo más destacable que tiene el juego son los villanos y ciertos enemigos; Los Rachini y los segadores son especies que llegan a causar verdadero terror y en cuanto al villano, puedes llegar a empatizar hasta cierto punto con Saren. También decir que el diseño de las distintas especies que hay en el universo está muy trabajado.

Mass Effect, a pesar de  ser un juego bastante original y único en muchos aspectos, es un mal juego. Si Bioware hubiese contado con más tiempo y experiencia previa, habrían sacado un auténtico juegazo. Por suerte, la saga mejora conforme se sacan más títulos (hasta llegar a Andrómeda, claro).

Having only played through this game ONCE, not out of disdain, but out of an ever expanding lIbrary, I can comprehensively say that I regret not playing this game when I had first heard of it. In terms of gameplay, its... relatively okay. I found it enjoyable, but it sort of boils down to a far more complicated V.A.T.S system from Fallout, combined with the action style of Gears of War, running cover to cover. Its character creator is amazing, however, with everything from personality to gear being customizable while in game. The voice acting is pretty good, the dialogues are incredible, ranging from funny and hilarious to downright heartbreaking. So many choices and decisions effect you later down the line, that it really makes you stop and think about what you're doing before you do it every time. With the announcement of a Legendary edition coming soon, I think I'll pick that one up too to play. I'm excited to see how it all pans out. For a simple numerical statsheet:
Gameplay: 7/10. Strange at first, gets better as you play. 
Graphics: 6/10. Defintely feels dated, but the good news is you shouldn't notice it too much in the heat of battle. 
Story: 10/10. Spanning three games, and if you count Andromeda, This is a story that should never be forgotten. You make it. 
Multiplayer: n/a, Pretty sure its all single player. Haven't tried any multiplayer with it. 
Should you continue the series: 10/10, This whole series is not one to be missed.

Take the time and make the effort to play it all the way through though as several mainstay characters for the series are already introduced here and the story provides the foundation of what's to come. The writing is excellent, the universe is colorful and full of interesting species, and every decision you make, large and small, will transfer to the story of the later games, be it in the form of some interesting commentary or new story arcs. 
I give it an 8/10 for what it achieved and its conclusion will lead to what I consider one of the best story arcs and single-player RPGs of all time: Mass Effect 2

I found replaying the game a delight and went for a full biotic build which was thoroughly enjoyable. 

For anyone returning to the series or new players, I should stress that once the final mission has been completed that is the end of the game and you do not have the ability to continue and finish the other quests. 77819307.review:
I played this game for the first time in 2020 and really enjoyed it. I bought it based off a recommendation saying it still lives up to the test of the time to new players today - and it really does. For a start, it's great being able to play as a female protagonist and feeling that your choices influence the world around you. I really liked the storytelling and the morality options. It's also such a hugely influential game as well - I felt like playing was almost a rite of passage. I could really feel all the energy and commitment that had been put into the game. I'm also really excited to see how my choices impact on the following games.

On the flip side, although there was nothing I could pinpoint about the relationships which was particularly grating (excluding the heteronormativity which is probably predictable for a game of its age), I didn't personally really buy into them that much - finding them pretty predictable. I'm sure there are others who would really like this aspect of the game however and there is the option to just leave it if it's not your thing.

TLDR: Really great game, 100% worth playing. Especially go for it if it's on sale!

76839120.review: The first game in one of the greatest series of all time. The largest and purest of the series, it has you exploring large parts of the galaxy, dropping onto planets and exploring in between hunting down Saren, a rogue Spectre who may be plotting the destruction of everything. The world building is fantastic. Each species is fully fleshed out with deep backgrounds the game's codex could have you reading for hours. The crew of the Normandy is one of the most memorable in all of gaming. The gun play and special abilites do get better in the sequels but this game is not to be skipped. The game has RPG elements, you choose the class your Shepard plays as and the abilities he or she uses and levels them up as you play. One of the greatest devices of the series is that the choices you personally make in this game affect the world of Mass Effect 2. Characters who lived and died and events that did or did not happen in your play thru could be completely different than someone else's play thru. And then your choices again carry over into Mass Effect 3. I've played thru the series several times just to see all the changes and avenues that I didn't explore before and always find something new. Mass Effect is one of the truly greatest series in gaming.

76085458.review:
Got to admit I did not think I would be writing a review for Mass Effect 1 but browsing through my library one day I saw that I had the game as well as the DLC for it now a bit of background and my own experience with this game, as far as I know there were two versions of this game when I first bought it back in 2012 for the Xbox 360 one being the “standard” version which contained no DLC and then the “Director’s Cut” I believe it was called, I bought the director’s cut as it was £2 more plus you get DLC as well as other little bits and pieces. I bought the game on what I had been told from an old friend “oh it’s a brilliant series I would recommend playing it” or something to that description. After purchasing the game, it took me 2-3 playthroughs of the introduction sequence to get into the gameplay and how the game would play out but, in the end, I completed the game and moved on to the sequel.After 6-7 years of not playing any of the Mass Effect series it has been a good time to come back to this starting off with the first.

ACTUAL REVIEW STARTS HERE

The game opens with a character customisation screen where you can create your own character from scratch with your own first name but you cannot change the second name (this might be down to the many voice lines that have already been done to fit for the name “Shepard” and also the symbolism behind the name Shepard which makes sense further down the line. I stuck with the default character and name because I’m not fussed with character customisation, I think this point of view might have been because of the Metal Gear Solid V fiasco with its ambiguous ending (another review for another time).

The game opens with you and your crew aboard the SSV Normandy flying through the vast reaches of space towards an Earth-clan planet “Eden Prime” where yourself and your crew find that its under attack with this spawns several plot points where the Commander (yourself) is brought into question by the Galaxy Council (an overarching political power that spans across the galaxies) and you then set out on you journey across the milky way coming across several characters with interesting backgrounds and several quests that question the moralities of the open space.

The overall game has been made out to be a clunky mess which in all honesty it is the way the characters move and the camera move already give the clunkiness away and if you see the sprint mechanic then it explains it, I do honestly feel that this game was an amalgamation of different mechanics that was slapped together with no clean up intended but in all honesty I love it because it works for a game introducing a world that has been built from scratch and for something trying to find its way which in its sequel seems to have been narrowed down more.

The RPG elements of the game are something that I wish were adapted into the later games but for a few different reasons I can understand why it was streamlined in 2 and 3, when you level up you are brought to a screen with various points categories (assault rifles, shotguns, pistols etc.) but it goes a bit more in depth with spending points on Paragon and Renegade categories which is your basic Good/Evil points if you want to be good spend points in this category and vice versa. These points do you make you stronger, but god does it make you work for it in the early levels.

Making conversations is the name of the game with the type of storytelling this game holds dear, making sure to know your crew is one way to proceed down a good path in this game so make sure to talk to people who are important ( yeah I know its awkward to say that but once spending a bit of time in the game you’ll be able to pick up who will advance your character and who won’t).

Sometimes the direction of where the game is wanting you to go can be confusing to read so be sure to read your journal and map to see where your points of interest are else you’ll get lost really quickly (like I did).Overall, the game is great but there is one thing that brings the game to a stuttering halt and its not the quiet moments . . .. it’s the areas where you must drive a planet rover to get to a location the way this thing controls it sucks ass. Overall a great game that I would recommend especially if you want to introduce yourself to a saga if you can put up with the clunkiness and sort of bugs that this game has then definitely play this but in all honesty one tip. . . . . SPAM AUTOSAVE FOR GODS SAKE!

8/10

76042481.review:
What is Mass Effect ?

Playing the first game for the first time and this being my very first contact with this franchise as I plan to play them in order in 2020, Im 13 years late to Mass Effect but better later than never ? Im truly happy that I had the chance to play this amazing game that mass effect is and finally discovering a new franchise that I missed back then never felt so welcoming, mass effect receives you with open arms and introduces you to this new, jaw dropping universe full of interesting lore and characters and the whole story that shepard has go to through from beginning to end was truly one of the most memorable game experiences I had in a while, theres nothing much to add of value in a review of a game that has been played and recommended to death, Mass Effect 1 is a true masterpiece that every fan of scifi should play at least once.

As the first game in the series it may have a few flaws and some dated mechanics in its gameplay particularly the vehicle sections and some early combat encounters, they were still figuring what mass effect could possibly be and probably fixed some of those issues in the sequels but dont let those aspects of the gameplay distract you, they didnt make the gameplay bad to me, just a bit hard to adapt in the first few hours. 

Mass Effect shines by presenting you with a world with no equal, crafted beautifully, I may have had a few issues with the gameplay initally like I said above but it had a nice sense of progression and it became better as I built my character, the story had me from beginning to end and the soundtrack was there to keep me engaged all the moment, once I saw the credits roll, all I had was goosebumps and a smile on my face, I was truly satisfied with what I played and that's surely an experience that I couldnt ask better for, even in 2020 mass effect 1 still kicks ass, so what are you waiting for ? just play the goddamn game, while I'll now start my playthrough of mass effect 2.

76001753.review:
This based on my third play through of ME1- I remember being blown away by this game the first time I played it and while it isn't as much of a slog to go through as other Bioware games (Dragon Age Inquisition I'm looking at you) the flaws in it's game design start to show after a few extended hours. However, I still highly recommend this game, the story is amazing and is something I think every gamer or fan of sci-fi should experience at least once. 

The game play is a blend of RPG and third person shooting games, which was quite a novel idea when it came out and honestly hasn't been implemented well or really built upon in any other game series that comes to mind. Instead of finding swords or axes and magical gems to enhance them you are finding shotguns or assault rifles and weapon mods. Instead of magic you have special "biotic" abilities or tech based skills like hacking into AI's. The choices you make matter, and the characters you encounter are all memorable. 

Most important thing to do if trying to run ME1 on modern machines:

- Getting this to run on modern machines smoothly is a bit of a pain- there's a "black box" glitch where in certain levels of the game all characters become black smudgy boxes and it's impossible to figure out what is going on. There are some mods that are hit-or-miss that fix this, and some console commands create a temporary fix but make the game look ugly AF. The best workaround is to download the MEUITM mods - never encountered any graphical errors from this and it makes the game look AMAZING. 

Here are the only bad things I can say about ME1: 

- Encountered a few glitches where my character would get stuck on some part of the map or some enemies would get stuck behind a door/within something else prompting me to reload the game to move forward. Happened a few times, and I'm not entirely sure if this was caused at all by MEUITM. More of an annoyance, but should be noted.

- The MAKO - this particular aspect of the game hasn't aged well at all. This is your all terrain vehicle that is part of a few missions in the game, and part of the bulk of the side missions in the game. While it is cool to visit these new planets to search for alien relics, respond to distress signals, or even blow up a rogue military combat AI on the moon, it painfully slows down the game's pace. The MAKO has a pretty powerful cannon and a machine gun that is good at whittling down enemy shields, but it handles so poorly and unpredictably that it makes it's sections become painful to go through. Either the MAKO is too slow for some of the massive maps, or the maps are just too big for the MAKO's top speed- I can't tell. The side-mission maps are pretty barren, with only 3-5 points of interest usually, and it's rarely got a few enemies. 

- The layout of pretty much all the side-missions outside of the Citadel are either these warehouse complexes, or underground bunkers on barren planets or these freighter ships with more or less the same layout. Yeah there might be some boxes in different locations, but the visual aesthetics and general layout is the same. They become noticeably predictable after a few encounters.

- Combat starts off pretty good- the balance is between skill-based shooting and squad/ability tactics against certain enemy types. Certain ammo types are good against certain enemies or provide elemental damage. The problem is later on in the game it doesn't really feel like the enemies scale up with you. What feels like hundreds of armour and weapon types all feel the same (outside of some visual aesthetics) and by the time the weapons feel different (the Geth assault rifle in particular) it's close to the endgame - and you'll have much better weapons by that point. I had done every side quest before doing the final story missions and I would barely have to be in cover to kill most enemies. The only times I died was from rocket launcher wielding enemies which pretty much kill you in one or two hits - and those deaths just felt cheap. This isn't really a problem with the game, but more so with how well the game has aged. Combat in the other games is significantly better. This traditional levelling RPG system for weapons and armour just doesn't really work with the way the cover-based shooting mechanic works. Later games would make weapons and armour revolve around the shooting mechanics and the RPG elements would be strictly limited to the dialog options and character/tech development paths. 

- The load times in this game are pretty much a meme these days. The long elevator rides - while offering some interesting conversations with characters in your party at times, are painfully obvious as ways to load the next area. Transitions between areas and even just getting place to place takes a bit longer than it does in most modern games. Playing the game for the first time this never really bothered me and it definitely doesn't break the immersion in the game, but is something that should be noted. There are mods that can speed up transitions.

In conclusion:

You should DEFINITELY play this game if you are interested in the ME series or just want to play a good RPG with a sci-fi theme. Playing this for the story is what your goal should be. Definitely play this if you have any interest in playing ME2 or ME3, as your choices will carry over into those games.

75712434.review:
"Mass Effect," the beginning of an incredible saga, is an iconic game that holds a special place in the hearts of many fans. Before diving into the review, it's essential to note that there's another version available, "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1328670/Mass_Effect_Legendary_Edition/]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/url]," a fully remastered compilation of the first three ME games. While some OG fans might have preferences due to visual differences, the remaster surpasses the original in several aspects, including visuals, gameplay, and bug fixes. The remaster also includes one of the two ME1 DLCs without external installers. Although the original has an additional DLC, it's not a compelling reason to choose it over the remaster. The remaster offers the complete ME trilogy and its DLCs at a significantly lower price than the originals combined. You can check my review for the remaster [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/recommended/1328670?snr=1_5_9__402]here[/url].

For newcomers or players looking to experience one version of the first Mass Effect game, I highly recommend checking out the remaster. Both versions hold their charm, but I personally prefer the remaster for its enhancements.

While I'm unsure of the game's state at launch, there are apparent issues that affect the experience. Thanks to PCGamingWiki and dedicated Mass Effect fans, there are ways to enjoy the game despite these problems. Following a comprehensive guide before playing is crucial to avoid potential problems. [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2450534696]Check mine out.[/url] The game's stuttering issue, especially for AMD users, can be persistent, but overall patches and updates have improved the experience.

Now, onto the game itself. "Mass Effect" captivates players from the start with its outstanding narrative and world-building. The story, characters, and alien races are fascinating, immersing players in a captivating cosmos. Engaging character hubs, conversations, decisions, and consequences shape a personalized Shepard journey, forging a deep attachment to the protagonist.

While the gameplay might not be groundbreaking, it remains great. The combat mechanics are solid, and the RPG elements are well-executed, contributing to the game's allure. Though the squad mechanics might be an acquired taste, they add depth and strategy to the experience.

Exploring planets in the iconic Mako might be divisive, as beautiful visuals clash with monotonous environments. Yet, landing on these planets remains a breathtaking experience with awe-inspiring landscapes and skies.

A key point to keep in mind is that "Mass Effect" lacks post-game exploration and side-mission completion after finishing the final main mission, setting it apart from other RPGs.

For achievement hunters: one minor disappointment is the absence of in-game achievements on Steam, regardless of earning all 49 of them. It's unfortunate that others won't witness these achievements. I can share my progress only by [url=https://imgur.com/gallery/KdEyLG9]screenshots[/url], on my [url=https://backloggery.com/games.php?user=ciocolici&search=Mass+Effect&alpha=1]Backloggery[/url], or written by myself on my [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/]Steam profile[/url].
If you do decide to still do them, you're in for a ride, my friend. I have 143 hours in this game. And that does not even include the time I've spent on the Origin version I own (now EA App). Although I don't remember how much time it took me to beat the game, you can be sure it wasn't 100. The achievements in this game are outrageous. Very grindy. You need a lot of time and patience. A shame I can only see them in-game.

In conclusion, "Mass Effect" is a remarkable and memorable game with a captivating story and enjoyable gameplay. Though it faces some challenges, it remains a masterpiece and the gateway to an unparalleled video game series. If you're ready to embark on a thrilling intergalactic journey, Mass Effect is the game for you.

75533742.review:
(note: mostly played on XBOX 365)

I consider the Mass Effect trilogy my second favorite game(s) of all time. But I'll get straight to the point: the gameplay of the original Mass Effect sucks. However, I really wished I played it before Mass Effect 2 because the story is so good and it is a true trilogy (unlike the Witcher were only a few sentences are of importance going into the next game).

But here's the rub: would I have finished Mass Effect if I played it before the sequel? Maybe not, because again, the gameplay sucks. So it really depends on how willing you are to go through it. But then again, who's to say you'll like the gameplay in the sequel? I like it, but maybe you won't, and then you've forced yourself through the game for naught. But even in that case, the story is still really REALLY good.

I recommend playing on easy. Could you just watch a video on YouTube? Probably, but Mass Effect is still an RPG at heart, and the choices you make carry over to the next game. Also, the experience and pacing of going through the game yourself is still miles ahead of just watching someone else play. If the gameplay is truly unbearably though, I don't think it's such a bad idea to watch a video. But do watch the video! Mass Effect 2 is a direct sequel to this game and the experience will be tons better if you know the story of the first.

75280893.review:
The real question is not if Mass Effect is a good game. The question is if it holds up today.
The graphics are (as expected) outdated. A remaster may come for this franchise, maybe if EA and Bioware need a quick buck. 
The mechanics and the gameplay are a bit old too. The gunplay is not as precise as it should be, the skill tree feels strange (the auto-level up is the most safe option), the equipment choices feel like random numbers that go up. It is almost like a mutation hybrid of a looter-shooter, a rpg and an exploration game, in which the gameplay succeeds at all but excels in none. 
The story and the choices are its strong card. Mass Effect tells a most compelling sci-fi story about a forthcoming apocalypse in which Commander Sheppard (the protagonist) tries to avoid. The plot, the characters and the choices are of pure quality and beat a lot of modern games that should take notes from this game.
So, does it hold up? I'd say yes. Even if the industry has come a long way and has improved in many ways, Mass Effect shows that some things never get old or outdated: A good compelling story, relatable characters and putting passion in the work of a game.

75141447.review:
Mass Effect is still fun, 12 years later. I highly recommend, especially if you're a fan of the other games. Here's what I think.

CONS:
Graphically, it has not aged well. The graphics weren't "great", even in 2008. Yet, it looks good enough for nostalgia.
The controls weren't refined yet. Sometimes, it's frustrating trying to do simple things, such as stick to walls. Not too bad...
Decisions have little impact on the ending. There are small variations but nothing surprising.
Some of the side missions are boring, honestly. I hate fetch quests.

PROS:
The story is fantastic, although there are moments of too much dialog. You'll find your deeply immersed, after a few games. The reapers were terrifying!
The music fits so well that I can't imagine the Mass Effect soundtracks sounding any other way.
Despite your decisions not seriously impacting the end, the events leading up to the end are a little more dynamic than I give it credit.

OVERALL:
Mass Effect is still one of the best video games EVER and I stand by that, despite the annoying flaws. What it lacks in gameplay mechanics, it more than makes up for in story and character development. Just imagine. The sequels were actually much better. That's the mark of a good story. Hollywood could learn a thing or two.

74882888.review:
A masterclass in world building that sucks you in with it's incredible atmosphere and compelling story that is just as grandiose and expansive today as it was 13 years ago. 

The standard Bioware companion formula was in the beginning of it's glory days as this game released with interesting and peculiar race representatives all aboard the Normandy. Liara was a particular favourite companion of mine, along with the always welcome Garrus, whose straightforward demeanour gives way to a frustrated veteran keen to make an impact. Wrex is another highlight, a mercenary who faces extinction along with the rest of his race caught in a conflict for the entire galaxy. 

Combat is an odd mix of dice rolls and 3rd person shooter that doesn't require precision but encourages smart cooldown usage and team composition particularly on harder difficulties. The party composition also allows for unique dialogue on main missions and insights from multiple campaigns (take Liara to Noveria!).

A great introduction to the series that starts great, slows down to a crawl to introduce you to the galaxy and shoots off again for a very fun and interesting 25 hour romp.

74444148.review:
Quality game. Make sure you download the DLC. It can all be found for free elsewhere online through genuinely legal channels, but isn't available on Steam for some reason.  

The game is good. It runs well. It looks like a pretty game from 2008, but it is obviously still from 2008. Make sure you turn off the film grain in the graphics menu. It makes the visuals much better.

The story structure follows the Bioware formula, but is overall well told and interesting all throughout. The sidequests can be dull, but all the main content is engaging. The morality system feels dated and overly-simplistic, rewarding ethical min-maxing over roleplaying. The story is enhanced fairly dramatically by playing a female main character as the male voice-actor feels very wooden. The rest of the voice talent in the game is excellent, so it's strange that they dropped the ball on the protagonist. The female voice actress is quite good though, so just play as a girl and you'll be fine. 

Gameplay is fun. There's a strong difficulty spike when you first leave the Citadel as the game adjusts to your character's newfound freedom, but everything before and after isn't too challenging. I prefer to play on Veteran difficulty. Soldier is the easiest class and the most consistently useful all throughout.

I've played the game on console before, but no longer have access to it, so I got it on PC to scratch the action-RPG itch. I would recommend the game for anyone desiring the same.
