74289497.review:
The period between 2007 and 2010 is what I would consider to be the Golden Age of BioWare. They had a string of straight back to back hits with the first two Mass Effect games and Dragon Age: Origins. While DA was more of their traditional bread and butter, ME was whole new territory, and thankfully, they succeeded. Well over a decade after its initial release, however, its flaws have become more pronounced, but the fact that I still love going back to play through it to completion speaks volumes to its overall staying power.

You take on the role of Commander Shepard. You'll recruit various characters to your mission and make difficult decisions that not only affect you personally, but the galaxy as a whole. ME may take cues from many well-known sci-fi properties, but they were also able to put their own spin on them, with various races with their own distinct style, personality and culture. More importantly, your party members are interesting and fun to talk to. The more I play ME, the more I appreciate certain details about this game that I never did the first time around.

At its core, it is an RPG with elements of a third-person shooter. The general shooting mechanics, on their own, are functional but not nearly as smooth as their contemporaries. You can be either a Soldier with access to every available weapon and armor, Biotic with magic-like force abilities but with a limited load out, or Engineer that can break hard-to-crack safes and mess with synthetics. Depending on your class you'll need to choose a team that best suits your needs.

One of the defining characteristics of Mass Effect is its emphasis on choice. Right out of the gate you can choose a basic background for Shepard, which can effect how characters interact with you and what side missions would be available. How you interact with people fills up either a Paragon or Renegade meter that further unlocks additional choices you can make. This system isn't perfect, but still gets the job done.

As I've said, ME has definitely begun to show its age. While the game for its time looked incredible, some of the environments come off rather dull and uninspired. Conversations with characters are also pretty static, but thankfully the solid voice acting carries them through. General sound editing is all over the place and much of the music is repetitive and rather forgettable. Mako is simultaneously floaty and stiff, making traveling on more rugged terrain a nightmare. There are a good variety of planets to explore, but most don't contain much to do. Much of the sidequests take place in like four locations that are laid out exactly the same and it is visually dull, and yet I still go out of my way to do each of them because there is still an addicting quality to the exploration and side missions.

While far from perfect, I still believe ME is definitely worth looking into, especially since you can import your save data into ME2 and see where things progress. I'd say you can probably get away with calling the original ME a "flawed masterpiece". Dated in many respects, but a classic nonetheless.

74003757.review: here is some advice that will literally never come in handy: how do you dogfight in space? Well, first I want to talk about something called Starbucks' rule in the Ronald Moore Battlestar Galactica episode "scar" from season two, Starbuck gave a younger and newer pilot some advice which says in so many words "turn into every attack never run, run and you're dead" now while this doesn't turn out brilliantly in the episode because the young pilot seems to be something of an idiot, this advice is almost always incredibly important because the first thing you need to understand about dogfighting in space in any kind of science fiction setting: there's contrived reasons for there to be dogfighting in space, they have to understand that there is no atmosphere and there is no ground, you're fighting in a vacuum that is almost always free of anything that could be described as terrain, now in an environment like this almost everything will be able to turn on a sixpence, there's no air resistance, nobody's going to be banking slowly, it's going to be far more difficult to predict people's movements because they're going to be able to change them far more quickly -- and if you're caught in a turning battle with another fighter you're trying to stay behind them and they're trying to stay behind you and then suddenly for some reason you want to get away because you've run out of missiles or your fuel's low and you feel like you need to ditch the engagement. That advice Starbuck gave suddenly becomes incredibly apparent because if you break off...you die...you can't escape a dogfight like this because if you're suddenly flying away in a straight line and they're suddenly in a straight line to pursue you there is a massive window of opportunity where you've got your back pointed at them and get out of range which will be 6 or 7 seconds minimum, if you're that close and suddenly present a static unmoving target that can't fire back for a few seconds anybody with even basic competence will shoot you down let alone a hyper-intelligent Cylon Raider, so what Starbuck suggests instead is that you continue to turn into every, attack no matter how badly it's looking, no matter how screwed you seem to be the, best bet is always to keep turning and keep trying to win.

73996119.review:
[b]Mass Effect | ★★★★☆[/b]

I started this game with a high expectation and finished it satisfied. It established a very deep world not because they show it visually but because they explained it too well. NPC's have a lot of information to fill you in more than you asked, Creating a well existence of Culture/Histories of creatures that you'll eventually know.

The gameplay rely heavy on being a Tactical Cover Shooter. At first, I thought the mechanics would be closer to Dead Space but turns out it was more like Spec Ops: The Line. Overall the game is great. The story is out there with the best. I can't believe the game doesn't have a TV series yet.

73968319.review:
It's impossible to evaluate Mass Effect on its own, as the trilogy really forms a coherent - and amazing - gaming experience, seamlessly as few game series (outside the other BioWare classics) do. You'll find it hard to argue against anyone placing the ME trilogy in the top10 games of all time.

Personally, I first played through ME2 and ME3, and went back to ME1 to experience the rest of the lore, which the first title delivers in heaps. In the latter parts, BioWare ups their game on fleshing out characters and combat, respectively, but you really want the full Mass Effect treatment.

While ME1 is the most dated, revealed by somewhat stiff RPG and combat mechanics, it sets the stage for an epic story with its excellent worldbuilding and political intrigue. It still looks great (and even better with the high-quality mods available), and the atmosphere of the main plotline is palpable, with several scenes sending chills up your spine.

I'd perhaps recommend keeping the difficulty level modest, grabbing a few quality-of-life and visual mods, and enjoying the story.

73927895.review:
In 2020 ME still has a lot of things going for it. The character building, dialogue, and general meaningful options to make are great. Starting here to build a character, and bringing them through the series still feels really rewarding. That said...

This game has not aged all that well in many other areas. It's not terrible, but the combat and AI are both EXTREMELY clunky and difficult to deal with. It feels like your squad AI is virtually non-existent, but spending time telling them what to do is also futile because they will typically do nothing and die regardless of instruction. (maybe every button secretly maps to "DIE ASAP") Combine this with ULTRA AGGRESSIVE ENEMY AI (sprinting straight at you and pummeling you to death, hiding directly behind closed doors with shotguns/rockets... even AI in DOOM wasn't this obnoxious) it can get a bit annoying. Also, you die REAL fast. Many times I have no idea how it even happens. Probably my fault, I guess. 

Here is the real problem: Most of my play sessions end with the game crashing, bugging out, glitching, or somehow otherwise finding ways to reset my progress 30+ minutes at a time. The autosave function in this game is nearly worthless (it seems only to save at critical mission junctures, not on a timer or with any regularity) forcing you to CONSTANTLY auto-save, or risk being cheese'd by enemy AI, or the game just straight up freezing and forcing you to alt+f4 out. 

TLDR; I want to play back through the ME series. I will deal with this crap to get my character from ME1 --> ME2, but I'm not happy and honestly am going to finish ME as quickly as possible. Which, in just under 10 hours, pretty sure 10-20% of that has been replaying spots I already beat due to game bugs.

I remember my squadmates actually being useful and following orders but they don't here. Lastly, there are still a host of un-resolved bugs. 73590791.review:
I probably put well over 100 hours into this game on XBox 360 over ten years ago. I've wanted to do a full ME trilogy run for a long time now as I simply never had time to play the third when it was released. I was dreading replaying this one as I remebered the combat being pretty dated (it's a 13 year old shooter after all). Well here we are. 67 hours to do three playthroughs and 100% the title. 

The combat does still feel dated but it plays cleanly. The RPG elements, story, and world building are second to none. Playing on the harder difficulties can be kind of a slog as some of the enemy abilities make them simply unkillable for an extended period of time. And having to drive the Mako can be the most frustrating and pointless experience in any game I remember. Straight up this game is in my top 3 all time without that thing.

Even with it this game holds up and will give you hours of enjoyment even for just one playthrough to kick off one of the best video game story arcs of all time. 9.2/10

73453744.review:
This game is so needlessly hard I can't even get past the tutorial. 

I quit in frustration when I bought this several years ago, but I gave it another go today. Nothing's changed. Your squad mates act like utter buffoons, standing out in the open when fired upon. It's quite irritating, but manageable... until the end of the tutorial mission, when you're given five minutes to prevent bombs from blowing up a train station. You cannot do this solo: if you try, you will die. Instead, you must rely on your idiot underlings to fire at aliens while you prance around hopelessly searching for the charges. It's not very fun.

I suppose I could replay it over and over until I know exactly where the charges are, exactly when the enemies will attack. But what's the point? It's the tutorial mission. If I can't get past this on "normal" difficulty, there's no way the rest of this game will be anything but piss-poor, jaw-clenching aggravation. 

I'm happy I got this on sale, but it was still a waste of money and time.
